content: Hindsight may be 20/20, but with some studying, your stockpicking foresight can get pretty good, too.Foreseeing the move by a stock with terrific fundamentals, a No. 1 ranking in its industry, and loads of fund sponsorship, before it happens is crucial. If such a stock breaks out with force, then you're more likely to grab shares at the proper buy point.Think of the "buy point" as the ground floor of a potential elevator-like advance to new highs. It's not enough to just buy the right stock. You have to buy the right stock in the right way at the right time.Those who read Investor's Corner regularly have a strong command of one of the most important patterns in growth investing: the cup with handle. The pattern allows you to be consistent in your buying. You're essentially entering a stock only when it's reached the point in which it can rise fast in a relatively short time frame.Human nature hasn't changed. Greed and fear still drive the market. So the cup with handle and other useful patterns of investor behavior will continue to pop up among IBD's wide span of features and screens designed to help you find and buy great stocks at the right time.Make a habit of going through the stocks presented in IBD 50, Big Cap 20, Stock Spotlight, Sector Leaders, IPO Leaders and Stocks Near A Buy Zone. Most of these can be accessed via Stock Lists on the home page at Investors.com. (See the Income Investor columns by clicking on "Research" on the main navigation bar on the home page.)Get these newsletters delivered to your inbox & more info about our products & services. Privacy Policy & Terms of UseAre you completely new to chart analysis, or want to bring your skills up a notch? Check out the real-time annotations done in Leaderboard, which debuted in July 2011.A buy point is a price level at which a stock is most likely to begin a significant advance. It also points to an area of the chart that offers the least amount of resistance to price progress.Where that point is depends on the type of base the stock has formed, whether a cup with handle, a cup without handle, a flat base or double bottom.This is the critical moment. Identifying the correct buy point can make all the difference between a successful investment and a losing trade. And before you buy, always check that the Market Pulse table, updated every day in The Big Picture column, shows the current outlook as "Market in confirmed uptrend."Let's look first at one of the easiest buy points to spot: one from a cup without handle.In this type of base, the stock declines as much as 30% to 33% from a recent 52-week or all-time high, then starts to recover in a process that takes at least six weeks to complete. Once the ascent begins, there are no significant pullbacks, or anything that might be considered a handle.The buy point on this pattern is easy: 10 cents above the peak in the left side of the pattern.The flat base isn't much different. When the stock recovers and is 10 cents above the base's prior highest point, that's when you jump in.As the stock approaches new highs — building the right side of the cup pattern — the stock suddenly pulls back moderately in price. This pullback is up to 15% in depth but can be much less. According to IBD research, most handles in the most successful stocks show a drop of no more than 8% to 12% from the handle's highest price.Also, a good handle will form within the upper half of the base. How can you tell? Sometimes you can see it visually. Maybe the handle began forming when the stock was just a few points below the cup's left-side high.When it's difficult to tell, what should you do?Use the midpoint test. Add the highest price and lowest price within the cup, then divide by 2. Do the same with the handle.If the handle's midpoint is higher than the base's midpoint, a breakout has a better chance of succeeding. The stock has already shown strong demand by climbing off its lows, plowing past prior price levels in which some shareholders had bought and immediately harbored paper losses. As a stock rebounds, these folks eagerly sell and get rid of the stock.Use the highest level in the handle area and add 10 cents to derive the buy point.Take Seacoast Banking (SBCF) as an example from 2016. After the Donald Trump presidential election win on Nov. 8, bank stocks took off. Florida-based Seacoast joined the bandwagon with a gusher of a move from Nov. 9 to 14, rising as much as 9% during that time frame and clearing an 18.05 handle buy point on a nine-week cup pattern.The midpoint of the cup was 16.83 (15.85 + 17.80 divided by 2). The handle's midpoint of 17.38 (16.82 + 17.95 divided by 2) was higher, so it passed. As seen in Seacoast's case, sometimes, the handle may begin forming slightly above the cup's left-side high.The double-bottom base is a bit different. The stock forms a cup pattern, but makes another correction before it reaches new highs. The second bottom usually is lower than the first.The pattern has a W-shape. The buy point is the middle intraday peak of the W-shape plus 10 cents. Keep in mind that a handle may also form, presenting an alternative entry.No matter what type of base it is, the stock should pass its buy point in heavy volume. That gives you the confidence big investors are buying as well.How much volume should you expect? Trading should swell at least 40% above the stock's 50-day average volume.If you're watching a stock during the trading session and aren't sure if volume is so strong, check the stock quotes at Investors.com. The volume percentage change is continually calculated.Nursing care facility operator VistaCare went public in December 2002 and by April 2003, it had formed a cup base with a high handle (1). The highest price in the handle was 19.Within the handle, the stock fell 11.6%, in range with the typical handle on a cup base during a bull market. Meanwhile, stocks were taking off and leading growth names were bursting out of bases after the market followed through on March 17, 2003, Day 4 of a new rally attempt. On that day, the Nasdaq soared 3.9% in higher turnover; the S&P 500 gushed 3.5% higher.VistaCare broke out on April 28, 2003, in heavy volume, then held above the 19.10 buy point two weeks later during a pullback that became a bullish reversal (2).On the breakout day, VistaCare showed decent ratings  on IBD Stock Checkup despite being such a young new public company: a 72 Composite, 80 EPS, 78 RS and A- for Accumulation/Distribution.Investors who bought at the correct buy point stood to more than double their money by year's end.(A version of this column was originally published in the April 16, 2010, edition of IBD. VistaCare was acquired by Odyssey HealthCare in March 2008. Also, please follow Saito-Chung on Twitter at @IBD_DChung for additional commentary on breakouts, top growth companies, and financial markets.)RELATED:Inside IBD 50: What To Do When Your Stock Has A Frightening Accumulation/Distribution GradeHow To Trade Smart: Invest Time In The Cup-With-Handle PatternHow To Read Charts Like A Pro, Part I: Focus On Daily Chart? Weekly? No, BothHow To Read Charts Like A Pro, Part II: Check The Time A Stock Spends Below The 10-Week Moving Average

Florida's GDP growth paints a brighter picture than the U.S. national average. In Q4, the U.S. growth rate was 2.9%, but Florida outperformed with 3.7% growth.Only two states topped Florida's growth rate in Q4 — Texas at 5.2% and Idaho at 4.8%.How can an investor profit from Florida's strength?Seacoast Banking (SBCF) is one way to play the Florida economy. Seacoast's annual earnings grew 57% in 2015, then 41% and 23%. The Street expects earnings growth of 37% this year.Get these newsletters delivered to your inbox & more info about our products & services. Privacy Policy & Terms of UseCEO Dennis Hudson said at the Q1 earnings call in late April that, "We benefit enormously by the strength and increasing diversity of Florida's economy."As of March, organic loan growth rose 9% in the past 12 months.Hudson noted that Seacoast Banking's main goal is organic growth. "If we can't produce organic growth, we shouldn't be in the business," he said at the call.The small-cap company sees acquisitions, which it occasionally makes, as supplementary. Acquisitions have to be "the right kind of M&A, that really fits with our strategy.""On the M&A front, there's still lots of opportunities in Florida," Hudson said. "We have a number of conversations underway and we'll just have to see how those go."In Q1, earnings grew 54%. Analysts expect 48% growth in Q2. After-tax margin was 28.5% in Q1, the best in at least 18 quarters.The company's 10-Q filed with the SEC noted that net interest income rose 30% in the first quarter. "Loan growth, balance sheet mix and increases in benchmark interest rates have been the primary forces" boosting net interest income, the company said.According to Hudson, Seacoast's success comes from "focusing exactly on the businesses we're best at, which is business banking." The company serves the small-business banking space.Seacoast Banking recently joined the Sector Leaders screen, which has IBD's most stringent requirements. How does Seacoast rate vs. its bank peers? Check it out in Stock Checkup at Investors.com.The stock is too extended to buy now, but could retreat to test its 10-week moving average for a possible entry.Get instant access to more trading ideas, exclusive stock lists and IBD proprietary ratings for only $5.RELATED:Sector Rotation: Who Will Be The Winners?The IBD Screen That Led The First Half Of 2018When To Sell: Is Your Stock Living Under The 10-Week Line?The Stock Indicator That Can Act Like A Canary In The Coal Mine

DSW reported better-than-expected first-quarter earnings on Wednesday, but the shoe retailer's stock fell sharply early.XEstimates: Wall Street expected earnings per share to rise 12.5% to 36 cents, as revenue declined 1% to $684 million, according to Zacks Investment Research. Consensus is for same-store sales to grow 2%, according to Consensus Metrix.Results: DSW earned 39 cents as sales grew nearly 3% to $712.1 million. Same-store sales climbed 2.2%.Outlook: DSW still expects full-year EPS of $1.52-$1.67. Analysts have forecast $1.62.Get these newsletters delivered to your inbox & more info about our products & services. Privacy Policy & Terms of UseStock: Shares fell 5.6% to 24.61 in the stock market today after sinking as low as 22.96 intraday. DSW had been trading at a two-year-plus high.DSW operates 517 stores across 45 states. It sells footwear from Nike (NKE), Adidas (ADDYY), Skechers (SKX) and others.Like other retailers, DSW is trying to make shoe shopping more flexible by offering customers more ways to shop online or have items shipped to them. Strong holiday sales, and sales in women's footwear, helped the company in the fourth quarter.The company is also still rolling out its DSW Kids sections across its locations — an effort to meet demand from children and their parents. DSW in March said it expects that rollout to be complete this year.Footwear chain Foot Locker (FL) closed flat. Shares of Foot Locker surged last week following the company's earnings. The stock is still within range of a 53.27 buy point of a consolidation pattern.Deckers (DECK), the parent of Ugg boots, popped 2.4%. Deckers also jumped following the company's estimate-topping results.YOU MIGHT BE INTERESTED IN:Michael Kors Earnings Top, But Stock Goes On ClearanceNike Scores On China's Basketball Boom, But Competition Rises At HomeSteve Madden Beats On Earnings; Skechers Plunges On Weak OutlookNew Option Strategy Limits Risk Around Earnings

The Dow Jones industrials and S&P 500 dipped 0.1% ahead of Friday's open. The Nasdaq Composite defended a narrow gain. Retail stocks were busy and crude oil prices were taking a sharp dive. Foot Locker (FL) and BioMarin (BMRN) led Friday's early advancers. Autodesk (ADSK) and Hibbett Sports (HIBB) fell hard after reporting quarterly results.Retailers bookended the S&P 500, with Foot Locker at the top and Gap (GPS) posting the largest decline. BioMarin topped the Nasdaq 100. Autodesk and Ross Stores (ROST) posted the index's worst early declines.The Dow received a boost from Nike (NKE), which rose 0.9% following Foot Locker's first-quarter report. Chevron (CVX) and Exxon-Mobil (XOM) brought up the rear among Dow industrials, down more than 2% each on a possible change in Saudi/Russia oil production quotas.All three of the leading indexes traded higher for the week through Thursday. The Dow Jones industrials were up 0.4% through Thursday. The S&P 500 gained 0.6%, while the Nasdaq Composite hauled in a 1% gain — leaving it less than 3% below its mid-March high.Durable goods orders dropped more than expected, falling 1.7% in April, the Commerce Department reported. The measure's first decline since January was larger than the 1.2% slip projected by economists. Minus transportation, orders rose 0.9% — a big jump from March's flat performance, easily outpacing analyst views for a 0.6% increase.Get these newsletters delivered to your inbox & more info about our products & services. Privacy Policy & Terms of UseCrude oil prices shed nearly 3%, sending West Texas Intermediate below $69 per barrel for the first time since May 8. Oil ministers from Russia, United Arab Emirates and Saudi Arabia met in St. Petersburg, reportedly to discuss unwinding the 17-month pact that has limited global oil output, and helped ease the impact of what had been a global oil glut. Saudi Energy Minister Khalid al-Falih said caps would be removed gradually, in order to avoid a supply shock.Oil prices could see additional impact when Baker Hughes (BHGE) releases its weekly rig count census at 1 p.m. ET.Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell is scheduled to speak at a banking conference in Sweden at 9:20 a.m. ET. Federal Reserve Bank presidents Robert Kaplan, Raphael Bostic and Charles Evans plan to participate in a panel discussion on banking technology, in Dallas, at 11:45 a.m. ET.Foot Locker spiked 13% following a solid first-quarter report. The heavy-volume gain lifted the stock briefly above a 53.27 buy point in a four-month cup base. Shares then eased to just below the entry price.Deckers Outdoor (DECK) jumped 3.4% at the open, after reporting healthy fiscal fourth-quarter results, but mixed first-quarter guidance. The gain left shares extended, beyond the top of a buy range, above a 99.02 buy point.On the downside, retailer Hibbett Sports sloughed off 11.9% after missing Q1 earnings targets.  Gap crumbled more than 10% after reporting an earnings miss late Thursday.Autodesk was down 3.2% and paring losses lower after its second-quarter earnings guidance disappointed analysts. The maker of computer-aided-design software reported adjusted earnings above analyst targets, with revenue in line. Autodesk shares had climbed for the past three weeks, building the right side of a two-month flat base.Across global markets, in Japan, Tokyo's Nikkei 225 inched up less than 0.1% Friday. That left the index down 2%, snapping an eight-week advance. China's markets posted moderate losses, with Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index ending the week down 1.4%Markets in Europe turned mixed in afternoon trade. Frankfurt's DAX led, up 0.4%, while the FTSE 100 in London and CAC-40 in Paris posted narrow declines.  All three indexes were tracking toward losses for the week of less than 1%.YOU MIGHT BE INTERESTED IN:The Big Picture: Stocks Hold Places, But This Sector Outperforms AgainAmong Top FANG Stocks, Here's Why Netflix Has Reached A New Buy PointForget Trump: This Is Why A Cold China Trade War Looms9 Ways To Profit From Trump Canceling Of North Korean Summit

Dick's Sporting Goods (DKS) turned in a beat-and-raise quarter Wednesday morning, sending shares spiking while also boosting Under Armour (UAA) and Nike (NKE).Profit in the first quarter grew 9% to 59 cents a share while revenue rose 5% to $1.91 billion, well above analyst views for EPS of 42 cents on sales of $1.88 billion. E-commerce sales rose 24%.Consolidated same-store sales fell 2.5%; not adjusted for a calendar shift, comps dipped 0.9%. Consensus Metric analysts had expected a 1.4% decline in same-store sales.The athletic apparel and goods retailer also raised its full-year EPS guidance to $2.92-$3.12, up from prior outlook for $2.80-$3. The midpoint of current guidance is higher than consensus for $2.93 a share in 2018.Shares rocketed 26% to 38.35 on the stock market today, trading back at July 2017 levels and retaking support at the 50-day moving average in heavy volume. The stock had been hitting some resistance at the key level since mid-April, dipping below the longer-term 200-day at points.Under Armour and Nike, two brands carried by Dick's Sporting Goods stores, rallied 3.5% and 1.85%, respectively.Get these newsletters delivered to your inbox & more info about our products & services. Privacy Policy & Terms of UseThe earnings lift is being felt throughout the athletic brand space. Smaller sporting goods retailer Hibbett (HIBB) rose 4.4%, retaking its 50-day after an earnings miss last week.Foot Locker (FL) was flat at 54.56 as it continues to trade in buy range after breaking out of an area of consolidation on Friday on the back of surprise quarterly profit growth. The stock cleared a 53.27 buy point to get there.YOU MIGHT BE INTERESTED IN: Boot-ilicious Results: Ugg Parent Decker Outdoors Jumps After Stomping On ViewsNike Scores On China's Basketball Boom, But Competition Rises At HomeNew Option Strategy Limits Risk Around EarningsIndexes Gain Early As Salesforce.com, Movado, Dick's Rise On Earnings

Sneaker chain Foot Locker (FL) and sporting goods retailer Hibbett Sports (HIBB) reported first-quarter earnings before the open Friday. Foot Locker topped views while Hibbett Sports fell short on earnings and revenue.XEstimates: EPS for Foot Locker to drop 8% to $1.25, marking its fifth consecutive decline, as revenue dips 1.3% to $1.97 billion, according to Zacks Investment Research. Same-store sales are expected to drop 3.6%, Consensus Metrix estimates.Results: Foot Locker reported a surprise earnings rise to $1.45 a share vs. $1.36 a year earlier. Revenue rose 1.5% to $2.03 billion. Same-store sales dipped 2.8%.Stock: Foot Locker shares leapt 20.3% to 55.81 on the stock market today, blasting through a 53.27 consolidation buy point. Nike (NKE), which makes up more than 60% of Foot Locker's merchandise, climbed 0.1%. Adidas (ADDYY) fell 1.1%. Under Armour (UAA) rose 1.3%.Get these newsletters delivered to your inbox & more info about our products & services. Privacy Policy & Terms of UseFoot Locker had already sounded cautious on Q1 results, saying they would continue weakness seen in Q4.Wedbush Securities analyst Christopher Svezia was upbeat ahead of the report, pointing to easier comparisons in the second half of the year, a moderating promotional environment, stabilizing Jordan distribution during the important back-to-school sales period, stronger product from Nike and gathering momentum in other brands."Strong full-price sales should generate positive merchandise margin in (the second half of the year) and more than offset higher store labor, supply chain costs, and e-commerce investments," Svezia said."We like the story going into 2018 as FL works diligently on savings, takes a balanced corresponding incremental sales for investment approach, enhances point of sale and its supply chain, works on elevating the consumer experience with partners, and benefits from increased allocations and a better product pipeline."Estimates: Wall Street sees EPS jumping 16% to $1.13 as revenue stays virtually static at $277 million. Same-store sales are seen rising by 1.2%Results: Hibbett earned $1.12 a share with revenue down a fraction to $274.7 million. Same-store sales dipped 0.3%.Outlook: The sporting goods retailer still sees full-year EPS of $1.65 to $1.95.Stock: Hibbett stock fell 15.6%.Hibbett Sports operates more than 1,000 stores, which are mainly located in small and midsize communities across the U.S. Its primary shop format a roughly 5,000 square foot store which draws inspiration from Walmart (WMT). They tend to be located in strip centers.YOU MAY ALSO BE INTERESTED IN:Boot-ilicious Results: Ugg Parent Decker Outdoors Jumps After Stomping On Views Nike Scores On China's Basketball Boom, But Competition Rises At Home New Option Strategy Limits Risk Around EarningsHow To Make Money In Stocks Using The CAN SLIM Investing System

Here's your Investing Action Plan for Friday: what you need to know as an investor for the coming day. Athletic gear chain Foot Locker (FL) reports earnings before the market opens, capping a heavy week of retail reports. The company's results will also have implications for shares of Nike (NKE), Under Armour (UAA) and Adidas (ADDYY). Foot Locker, Nike [ibd-display-video…

The stock market traded mixed on Friday, ahead of the three-day Memorial Day weekend. Early in the day, President Trump said his administration had restarted talks with North Korea — just one day after canceling a historic summit. Top computer software stocks Veeva Systems (VEEV) and Splunk (SPLK) were on the move after their respective earnings releases. Meanwhile, PayPal (PYPL) was trading near a potential buy point. (For updates on this story and other market coverage, visit stock news today)XThe S&P 500 and the Dow Jones industrial average declined about 0.1% each, while the tech-heavy Nasdaq moved up 0.2%.Among companies reporting earnings, Foot Locker (FL) jumped 13% after its Q1 earnings report early Friday. Shares were just below a potential 53.27 buy point.Veeva Systems reversed higher to add 0.6% after easily beating the Street's Q1 estimates. The medical software provider is above a 75.67 double-bottom entry and in buy range.Get these newsletters delivered to your inbox & more info about our products & services. Privacy Policy & Terms of UseSplunk moved up 0.5% after its Q1 earnings release late Thursday. The software maker reported better-than-expected earnings and sales, while forecasting a strong Q2 outlook. Shares are clinging to a recent 112.76 buy point.Deckers Outdoor (DECK) rose 5% after blowing past its fiscal-Q4 earnings targets. Shares are extended from a 99.02 buy point, according to MarketSmith chart analysis.PayPal (PYPL) reversed lower, falling 0.7% despite Stifel Nicolaus upgrading the stock from hold to buy with a 99 price target. The analyst believes that PayPal is in the early stages of transforming into a global payments platform. The stock is approaching a double bottom's 84.09 buy point, while the stock's relative strength line has drastically improved since the beginning of the month. The RS line measures a stock's performance vs. the general market.Energy stocks were big losers in morning trade Friday, as oil prices dropped nearly 3%. Top OPEC and non-OPEC producers are reportedly discussing options to raise crude production this year. Leaderboard member Marathon Oil (MRO) fell more than 4%, but remains extended from a 18.76 cup-with-handle entry.Top oil stock Continental Resources (CLR) slid over 4% and is approaching the 50-day line. Shares remain extended from a 58.99 cup-shaped base entry.Among the top growth stocks, FANG stock Netflix (NFLX) advanced over 1%. Shares are trading toward the top end of the 5% buy range from a 338.92 flat-base buy point.RELATED:Watch Foot Locker's Earnings But Nike's Stock: Investing Action PlanAlibaba Added To Sector Leaders; Who Joined The Other Stock Lists?Trump Cancels Kim Jong Un Summit, Citing North Korea's 'Tremendous Anger'Salesforce Rival With 400% Growth Is Cutting Investors Some 'Slack'Resurgent Internet Stock Breaks Out; 2 Other Leaders Near Buy Points

If you're looking for stocks that are setting up in a base ahead of their next earnings report, here's one that fits the bill: Seacoast Banking (SBCF). It's expected to report on Apr. 26 and is currently about 2% under a 28.54 entry. The base is a first-stage flat base.X Buying a stock just ahead of earnings can be risky since you typically don't have enough time to build a profit cushion before the latest quarterly numbers come out. Be sure to follow sound buy and sell rules to minimize your exposure.Looking For The Best Stocks To Buy And Watch? Start HereEarnings growth slowed in the most recent quarter from 21% to 19%. But revenue moved higher, from 24% to 61%. Analysts expect EPS growth of 50% for the quarter, and 38% growth for the full year. Annual growth estimates were recently revised lower.Seacoast Banking has a 94 Composite Rating and earns the No. 5 rank among its peers in the Banks-Southeast industry group. Southern First Bancshares (SFST) is the No. 1-ranked stock within the group.Note: Dates for earnings reports are subject to change. Check the company's website for any updates. Given that Amazon (AMZN) has 19 private-label apparel brands, many of them still in their embryonic stages, it might come as no surprise that the e-commerce dragon is eyeing sportswear as its next private label.XThe company is connecting with "some of the biggest athletic-apparel suppliers" as it looks to enter the privately branded sportswear industry, reported Bloomberg on Friday, citing people familiar with the matter.Amazon's bevy of in-house brands is large — 34, to be specific, according to Morgan Stanley — and its clothing collections include dressier women's lines such as Society New York, Lark & Ro and James & Erin, intimates lines Arabella and Mae, men's lines Franklin Tailored and Goodthreads, and Scout & Ro kids clothing.But it does not appear to have a dedicated sportswear line — something that could be taken advantage of as "athleisure" continues to be a trendy sartorial choice.Athletic apparel companies generally reacted poorly.Lululemon (LULU) fell 2.2% on the stock market today. So did Under Armour (UAA). Nike (NKE), the No. 1 athletic apparel brand in the world, edged up 0.3%.Apparel retail chains Foot Locker (FL) added 0.7%, but Dick's Sporting Goods (DKS) slipped 0.54.Morgan Stanley analysts projected Tuesday that Amazon's private-label brands could add $1 billion to its gross profit in 2019.Amazon shares rose 0.2% to 1,002.94.RELATED:Wal-Mart's Jet.com Debuts Private Label Uniquely J For 'Metro Millennial Lifestyle'Target's New Exclusive Brand? We Spotted It A Month AgoEXCLUSIVE: Will These Trademarks Be Target's New Private-Label Brands?

Nike (NKE) shares popped Wednesday after the athletic apparel and shoe giant reassured at its investor day that it still expects solid revenue growth over the next five years and sees a way out of the retail labyrinth that has confounded so many other brick-and-mortar-based brands.XOver the next five years, half of Nike's growth will come from "new innovation concepts," digital sales will rise from 15% to 30% of revenue, and nearly 75% of its growth will come from outside the U.S., said Nike Chief Executive Mark Parker from the company's headquarters in Beaverton, Ore.He is "very confident" that Nike's strategy, which focuses on speed to market, tighter product selection and a digital-focused consumer experience, will help drive high-single-digit revenue growth and midteens profit growth over that time frame.ICYMI: NIKE says at investor day that it sees high-single-digit revenue growth and mid-teens EPS growth over the next 5 years $NKE pic.twitter.com/VsocqIHQ3c— Elaine Low (@IBD_elow) October 25, 2017Meanwhile, CNBC reported that Nike is "on track" to hit $50 billion within five years, which presumably means 2022. At its prior investor day in 2015, Nike had forecast it would hit $50 billion by the end of fiscal 2020.Mark Parker confirms to @CNBC that @Nike is on track to hit $50B in five years. $NKE— Jess (@JGolden5) October 25, 2017Adidas' (ADDYY) current surge of popularity has been stronger than some expected, and Nike execs attempted to soothe any concerns that the Swoosh was losing its edge among teens."Consumers tell us that we are the No. 1 cool brand and the No. 1 favorite footwear and apparel brand for today's youth," said Nike Brand President Trevor Edwards, citing Nike's third-party tracking studies.And amid a rough brick-and-mortar retail landscape, Nike outlined a few ways it intends to fight to stay the No. 1 athletic apparel and shoe brand in the world."Make sure that nothing stands in the way of getting that consumer the exact product they want at the exact moment they want it," said Edwards.That includes Nike.com exclusive products, same-day deliveries in certain major cities, and pulling away from "undifferentiated" retail outlets, which appear to be stores that do not have stand-alone Nike-centered displays."Undifferentiated mediocre retail won't survive," said Edwards.The massive impact that Amazon and online shopping as a whole has wrought on retail is not lost on the brand. Management emphasized throughout the presentation that its focus now is making sales on Nike.com, Nike brick-and-mortar stores, and through strategic wholesalers. Currently 40% of the brand's wares are in what it terms "differentiated" spaces. It plans to take that up to 80% over the next five years.Execs also highlighted strategic partnerships with Foot Locker (FL), and online team-ups with marketplaces such as Zalando and Amazon (AMZN), adding that Nike would be launching more pilots with online marketplaces internationally in the coming months.The iconic brand is also integrating with WeChat, owned by Tencent (TCEHY), weaving  its Nike+ membership program with the popular China-based messaging platform.Nike shares rose 2.9% to 54.94 on the stock market today, closing just above their 200-day moving average. Nike edged higher in late trading, despite implying it would hit the $50 billion sales in 2022, not 2020.Nike hit a 2017 low of 50.35 earlier this month on concerns about high inventory and clearance sales. Nike hit an 18-month high of 60.53 in August.RELATED:Nike Flash Sale 'Unprecedented' As Teens Ditch Iconic BrandWhy Nike's Weak U.S. Sales May Be A Bigger Warning Than You Think

Nike (NKE) topped fiscal Q1 profit expectations late Tuesday while the dominant sports gear brand's North America revenue fell, signaling weakness in its largest market.Estimates: A 34% profit tumble to 48 cents a share on flat year-over-year revenue of $9.065 billion, according to Zacks Investment Research, though other estimates had the top line inching up to $9.08 billion.Results: EPS of 57 cents on revenue of $9.07 billion. North America revenue fell 3% to $3.92 billion, Europe-Mideast-Africa revenue rose 4% to $2.34 billion, greater China climbed 9% to $1.11 billion, and Asia Pacific-Latin America gained 5% to $1.19 billion. Nike brand revenue of $8.6 billion was up 2% on a currency-neutral basis. Converse revenue of $483 million was down 16% on a currency-neutral basis.Gross margin shrank to 43.7% from 45.5% due to foreign currency exchange rates and a higher mix of off-price sales. Nike management told analysts late Tuesday that the selling environment was promotional. Inventories were up 6% to $5.2 billion, driven by a higher average cost per unit primarily due to product mix."This quarter, we captured near-term opportunities through our new Consumer Direct Offense," said Chairman and CEO Mark Parker in a statement. "Looking ahead to the rest of fiscal 2018, we will ignite Nike's next horizon of global growth through the strength of our brand, the power of our innovative products and the most personal, digitally-connected experiences in our industry."Stock: Nike fell 3.2% late after ending the session up 0.9% at 53.70 in the stock market today. Under Armour (UAA) slipped 1.2%, and U.S.-listed shares of Adidas (ADDYY) fell 3.2% after an employee was embroiled in an NCAA corruption scandal that involved 10 arrests, including several college coaches.Nike also has been struggling from growing competition from Adidas, which has rapidly gained U.S. market share.Even Nike's iconic Jordan brand has looked less dominant, as basketball-shoe sales weaken and more fashionable shoes gain popularity. Adidas in particular has gotten traction from celebrity tie-ins, like shoes designed by rapper Kanye West.Meanwhile, Nike is experimenting with different distribution channels, such as selling some products directly on Amazon (AMZN) and Facebook's (FB) Instagram app.The efforts come despite Nike's strong push to sell directly to consumer through its own site and as traditional retail partners like Foot Locker (FL) struggle in the brick-and-mortar sales environment.RELATED:4 Shoe Stocks In Bases, Buck Nike-Under Armour Slumps: Investing Action PlanEarnings Calendar, Analyst Estimates And Stocks To WatchRetail & E-Commerce Stocks And Industry News

Retailers are still having a tough go of it. And a recent IPO was the catalyst for Thursday's troubles. But there were a few notable exceptions, including Amazon.com (AMZN) and Wal-Mart (WMT).XThe nearly sectorwide slide came in the wake of J. Jill's (JILL) late Wednesday warning that sales were lower than expected, cutting guidance. J. Jill, which came public in March at 13 a share, plunged 51% to 4.86 on the stock market today.Retail groups were among the biggest losers out of the 197 industries that IBD tracks, including the two worst performers.J.C. Penney (JCP) is hitting a fresh all-time low, falling 3.7%. Kohl's (KSS) briefly slipped below its key 50-day moving average for the first time since the start of September, retreating 2.1%.Teen bargain-retailer Five Below (FIVE) is testing its buy point after clearing the 54.23 entry from a period of consolidation in late September, slipping 1.8% to 54.99.Nike (NKE) dipped 0.4% after hitting a 2017 low intraday, as Bloomberg pointed out a 40% flash sale that one NPD analyst calls "unprecedented."Ulta Beauty (ULTA) is tumbling following a downgrade from Cleveland Research to neutral from buy, citing an expected slowdown in cosmetics and a rise in promotions. Ulta plunged 8.5% to an 18-month low.Upscale housewares chain Williams-Sonoma (WSM) retreated 3.6% on its own downgrade.Foot Locker (FL), Gap (GPS) and Macy's (M) were also significant losers, closing down 4.6%, 4.3% and 1.1%, respectively.IBD'S TAKE: Retail stocks have been offering shorting opportunities. Not sure where to start? Here's a primer in short selling. Amazon, meanwhile, hit a two-month high, rising 0.6% as it works on a flat base. And Wal-Mart, increasingly lauded for its e-commerce efforts over the last year or so, advanced 0.4%. Wal-Mart has surged 9% this week, just beyond a buy range after breaking out Tuesday on a bullish online sales forecast and $20 billion buyback.Wal-Mart is increasingly seen as the brick-and-mortar retailer most likely to hang with Amazon as many traditional chains fall further behind and risk going out of business.Target (TGT) was another winner Thursday. Shares rose 1.8% after retaking their 200-day line on Wednesday and their 50-day on Tuesday.RELATED:Wal-Mart Breaks Out On Buyback, Bullish Online Sales ForecastNike Flash Sale 'Unprecedented' As Teens Ditch Iconic BrandHere's An Inside Look At Nordstrom's New Store With No ClothesSee What Amazon's First Bookstore In Los Angeles Looks Like Death Stalks Retail Stocks, But Hope Lives On

The major indexes opened higher Wednesday, one day after the Russell 2000 small-cap index and Dow Jones industrial average hit record highs.XThe Nasdaq composite opened 0.6% higher while the Dow rose 0.3% and the S&P 500 0.4%.In a speech today at 3 p.m. ET, President Trump is expected to give details of a tax overhaul plan that most likely will dramatically lower rates for businesses to ignite economic growth. Money flowed out of bonds early, sending the 10-year Treasury yield higher by 7 basis points to 2.30%.In economic news, orders for durable goods rose 1.7% in August, above the consensus estimate of 1.5%. Excluding transportation, orders rose 0.2%, below the consensus estimate of 0.4%.Nike (NKE) was an early mover, down 4% after the bell, after the company reported disappointing sales late Tuesday. Shares of Nike haven't recovered much after gapping down Aug. 18 because of weak results from Foot Locker (FL), which carries a lot of Nike product.IBD'S TAKE: Shares of Nike might look cheap, but stocks are often cheap for a reason. Check out IBD University to see the seven characteristics seen in winning stocks before big price moves.Meanwhile, Micron Technology (MU) surged more than 5% at the open after the memory-chip maker reported strong earnings and sales and gave bullish guidance.Twitter (TWTR) added close to 2% on news it's testing 280-character tweets, up from the long-standing 140-character limit. Twitter has been struggling to attract new users as it sits about 34% off its high.RV maker Thor Industries (THO) was up more than 1% ahead of its earnings report after the close. It's been on a tear, up in 16 of the past 19 sessions, but it's also extended after a breakout from a base with a 110.01 buy point in late August.In IPO news, RYB Education (trading under the symbol RYB), a China-based provider of early childhood education services, priced last night at 18.50, above the proposed range of 16-18.RELATED:Twitter Will Double Character Count In Tweets During Test TrialMemory-Chip Maker Micron Crushes Fourth-Quarter Earnings Views Free Access To IBD Premium Content (9/25 - 10/8)

When Nike (NKE) reports first-quarter results after the close Tuesday, analysts expect a 34% profit drop to 48 cents a share on flat year-over-year revenue of $9.07 billion.XWhat's to blame for the expected sharp decline in earnings? A couple of key factors, say experts.Nike "appears to have misjudged the appetite for some key marquee basketball product," wrote Susquehanna analyst Sam Poser last week, downgrading the Swoosh to neutral from a positive rating. Now there's an "inordinate amount" of KDs, LeBrons and Kobe shoes on shelves, according to Poser's recent store checks."We do not believe the basketball business is dead," he said. "Rather we believe a recovery in the basketball category in North America may take longer than we initially anticipated as excess product is cleared."Cowen's John Kernan, who has a market perform rating on Nike, said he continues to see risk around the company's basketball business amid increased price-cutting in the category."We recently saw (Under Armour)'s Curry 3 priced at $75 and see little demand at price points above $120 across the entire category," said Kernan, adding that there has also been "significant" promotional activity in men's and women's athletic apparel and footwear.Piper Jaffray noted an approximate 40% year-over-year rise in clearance styles on Nike.com through the quarter. Add to that a slowdown in same-store sales and digital trends, and Nike "has yet to reach a bottom on its home turf," wrote analyst Erinn Murphy on Friday. She has a neutral rating on Nike.Nike shares rose 0.9% to 53.70 in the stock market today. The Dow component has been trading below its 50-day and 200-day moving averages after selling off in the wake of terrible results and guidance from athletic shoe retail giant Foot Locker (FL).Under Armour (UAA) dipped 1.4%, and Adidas (ADDYY) fell 3.2% to 110.13, falling below their 50-day line after an executive was implicated in an NCAA basketball scandal. Shares of the European shoe giant, which trades over the counter in the U.S., have pulled back since briefly hitting a record intraday high of 118.98.Then there's Adidas. That the brand is back isn't news to anyone. But those iconic three stripes may be here to stay, contrary to what some investors believe."In our view, the NKE bulls are still denying the durability of Adidas' resurgence, which we view as having longer growth sustainability," said Murphy.And Adidas has surpassed Nike's dominant Jordan brand to rank second among the top athletic-shoe labels in the country, said research firm NPD Group last week. Nike remains No. 1.Adidas has overtaken Jordan as the #2 brand in U.S. sport footwear. This is an achievement I never thought I would see in my lifetime.— Matt Powell (@NPDMattPowell) September 18, 2017Adidas' athletic-shoe sales grew to 13% of the U.S. market in August, tweeted NPD analyst Matt Powell.While some attribute Adidas' comeback to Kanye West's Yeezy designs for the brand, Powell is typically quick to bat away the assumption, tweeting that Adidas sales "were negative for two years after signing West."Where Adidas has shone is in the "classics" market, generating renewed interest in its retro Superstar and Stan Smith styles. Its Boost brand is also very popular."Adidas Primeknit continues to outperform Nike Flynit at the higher end consumer level, while Boost continues to outperform Vapor Max," wrote Cowen's Kernan earlier in the month.Powell said last week that it's "no surprise that Adidas is paying much more attention to shoe chains, where the brand's sales more than doubled," and that women's sales rose for the month.Women's sales led the pack with a 3% increase in

August, boosted by Adidas (updouble), while Nike women's sales continued to struggle.— Matt Powell (@NPDMattPowell) September 18, 2017Edward Jones analyst Brian Yarbrough remains optimistic on Nike's presence as a global brand.But a slowdown in athletic apparel fashion trends and stolen market share from rivals "will negatively impact sales growth and most likely cause earnings growth to slow over the next few years," he said.RELATED:4 Shoe Stocks In Bases, Buck Nike-Under Armour Slumps: Investing Action PlanTrumpCare's Last Gasp; Micron, Nike To Report: Investing Action PlanEarnings Calendar, Analyst Estimates And Stocks To WatchRetail & E-Commerce Stocks And Industry News

Sporting goods retailer Finish Line (FINL) late Monday slashed its full-year profit and same-store sales outlook, citing weakening sales and margin trends in a sector that has been shaken by the exodus to e-commerce.XThe company said it expected adjusted earnings per share for its full fiscal year to be between 50-60 cents, less than half its earlier expectations for $1.12-$1.23. Analysts expected $1.11 per share, according to Zacks Investment Research.Finish Line also expects a same-store sales decline of 3%-5%, compared with a previous forecast for "an increase in the low-single digit range."The company's preliminary second-quarter sales — down 3.3% to $469.4 million — also missed expectations."The marketplace for athletic footwear became much more promotional as our second quarter progressed resulting in challenging sales and gross margin trends," Finish Line CEO Sam Sato said in a statement.Shares sank 18.4% to 8.50 on the stock market today, falling as low as 6.90, their worst levels not seen since 2009. Nike (NKE) fell 1.9% and Under Armour (UAA) skidded about 3%.Shares of Foot Locker (FL), Dick's Sporting Goods (DKS) and Hibbett Sports (HIBB) this month also slid on weak quarterly results and guidance.Foot Locker lost 1.5% on Tuesday. Dick's fell 1.6%. Hibbett rebounded to climb 0.8%.While the athletic goods chains remain key distribution channels for Nike and Under Armour, Nike this summer also said it would run a pilot test to sell some products directly on Amazon (AMZN) even as it has focused on its own e-commerce site.RELATED:Foot Locker, Hibbett Sports Crash On Earnings, Outlook; Nike Falls Too

Mall-based athletic shoe retailer Foot Locker (FL) and Hibbett Sports (HIBB) tumbled to multiyear lows on weak earnings and forecasts for more of the same the rest of the year. Along with grim results from Dick's Sporting Goods (DKS) earlier in the week, the sporting goods sector continues to reel, with Amazon (AMZN) a growing threat.Meanwhile, Nike (NKE) shares also sold off, acting as a big drag on the Dow Jones industrial average.Foot Locker earned 62 cents a share in its second quarter, far below the 90 cents expected by analysts according to Zacks Investment Research. Sales fell 4.4% to $1.701 billion, also less than the $1.813 billion consensus. Same-store sales tumbled 6% vs. estimates for a fractional gain."Sales of some recent top styles fell well short of our expectations and impacted this quarter's results," CEO Richard Johnson said in the earnings statement. He also cited the lack of "innovative" products.Expecting those conditions to persist, Johnson sees Foot Locker comps down 3%-4% for the rest of the year.Foot Locker shares crashed 24% to 36.26 in morning trade on the stock market today, the lowest since early 2014.Athletic shoe and apparel giant Nike, which sells a lot of gear via Foot Locker, plunged 5.4% to 54.37, falling further below a 59.10 buy point. Nike recently agreed to start selling a limited selection of products directly on Amazon.Hibbett Sports lost 15 cents, better than the forecast 20-cent loss but only because Hibbett preannounced weak results in late July. Sales fell to $187.96 million, worse than revised estimates for $191 million. Same-store sales tumbled 11.7%, worse than Hibbett's preannouncement for a 10% drop. Gross margins plunged on heavy promotions and markdowns.Hibbett cut its full-year profit target to $1.25-$1.35 from $2.35-$2.50. Analysts had expected $1.74. Hibbett expects full-year comps to fall in the mid- to high-single-digit range.Hibbett shares fell 16% to 9.65 in intraday, their lowest since 2003. Hibbett had already fallen nearly 16% for the week through Thursday.Dick's Sporting Goods fell 2.3% in morning trade after diving 23% on Tuesday on its weak results to its worst levels in nearly seven years.RELATED:Stocks To Buy And Watch: Top IPOs, Big And Small Caps, Growth Stocks

The major market indexes were well off session lows in late morning trade, trying to find their footing after Thursday's big losses.X The tech-heavy Nasdaq rose 0.2% while the S&P 500 was fractionally higher. The Dow Jones industrial average lost 0.2%. The Nasdaq and S&P 500 gave up their 50-day lines on Thursday.Among the Dow industrials, global investment bank Goldman Sachs (GS) rose 0.7%. This week has seen the stock give up both its 50- and 200-day support levels.On the downside, Home Depot (HD) has declined four of the last five trading days, falling 1.2%. The stock had been forming a flat base, but this week's action has put the stock down near its 200-day line.Meanwhile, Apple (AAPL) rose 0.6% after Thursday's heavy loss. The iPhonemaker remains just above its 156.75 flat-base buy point.Retail stocks were once again under fire in the stock market today. Athletic shoe retailer Foot Locker (FL) reported weak earnings and same-store sales, prompting a 27% crash in the share price. The stock fell into the thirties, where it hasn't traded since February 2014. Since reaching an all-time high in December 2016, the stock has been more than cut in half in just eight months.Blue-chip Nike (NKE) fell nearly 4% in sympathy with Foot Locker. The Dow industrials athletic apparel stock has been struggling to gain traction after a breakout above a 59.10 flat-base entry. Friday's action triggers the 7%-8% sell rule.Meanwhile, sporting goods store Hibbett Sports (HIBB) guided its earnings forecasts significantly lower, sending its shares down 11%, hitting a 14-year low intraday The stock has fallen almost 80% from its 2016 high at 45.85.Chip leader Applied Materials (AMAT) advanced more than 2% after beating the Street's top- and bottom-line estimates late Thursday. The IBD 50 stock is forming a cup-with-handle base with a 47.69 buy point, but must first get back above its 50-day line.Among leading stocks, graphics-chip maker Nvidia (NVDA) edged up 1.3% as it attempts to stay above its 50-day line, which it reclaimed earlier this week.Also within the IBD 50, Control4 (CTRL) jumped nearly 11% after its inclusion in the S&P SmallCap 600. The stock is consolidating above the 50-day line after a strong move from a 12.70 buy point.On the downside, Chinese internet giant Sina (SINA) dropped 0.3% to just below its 97.90 cup-shaped base entry.RELATED:Foot Locker Earnings Miss Badly, Hibbett Sports Outlook GrimChip Stocks To Watch And Semiconductor Industry NewsDow Jones industrial average And Dow Stocks: News And AnalysisStocks Falter In Week Amid Trump, Terror, Retail, Earnings, But Alibaba BoomsRetail And E-Commerce News And Stocks To Watch

Dick's Sporting Goods (DKS) reported second-quarter earnings on Tuesday that were below analyst estimates, with the struggling retailer offering grim guidance for the rest of the year.XEstimates: Earnings per share of $1.01, a 23% jump. Revenue is seen climbing 11% to $2.176 billion, according to Zacks Investment Research. Same-store sales are expected to rise 1.8%, according to Consensus Metrix.Results: EPS of 96 cents and sales of $2.16 billion. Same-store sales rose just 0.1%. E-commerce sales rose 19%, accounting for 9.2% of net sales.Outlook: Dick's sees Q3 adjusted EPS of 22-30 cents vs. estimates for 55 cents. Dick's sees full-year EPS of $2.80-$3 vs. the consensus for $3.61, with full-year comps flat to down in the low single digits."We will be more promotional and increase our marketing efforts for the remainder of the year, as we will aggressively protect our market share," Dick's CEO Edward Stack said in a statement. "We have updated our outlook to reflect these investments. We continue to believe retail disruption creates opportunities for us as we look long-term."Shares plunged 17.8% to 28.69 in morning trade in the stock market today, a six-year low.Like most retailers, Dick's Sporting Goods operates in an increasingly e-commerce world. Shares of the company sank after news surfaced that Nike and Amazon (AMZN) struck a pilot deal to sell Nike products on Amazon directly.Hibbett Sports (HIBB) slid 6.1% while Foot Locker (FL) was off 5.1%. Hibbett Sports and Foot Locker report earnings later this week.Nike fell 1.4%, while Under Armour dipped 2.5%. Finish Line (FINL) lost 4.4%.RELATED:Amazon Looms Over These 5 Retailers Reporting Earnings: Action PlanBig Business Dumps Trump: Merck, Intel, Under Armour CEOs Quit CouncilAmazon Sales Deal In Focus As Nike Gets Ready To Report Q4 EarningsHibbett Sales — And Shares — Are The Worst Since The Financial Crisis

The S&P 500 index and Nasdaq composite neared record highs even as Hurricane Harvey devastated Houston, south Texas and parts of Louisiana. Gasoline futures spiked as refineries were shut, with consumers expected to see bigger increases in coming weeks. Biotech stocks broke out on the Gilead Sciences (GILD)-Kite Pharma (KITE) takeover deal and a historic FDA approval. The U.S. economy added fewer jobs than expected in August.The Nasdaq composite rose 2.7% for the week, closing a fraction below an all-time record high The S&P 500 index and Dow industrials also rallied to within 1% of all-time levels. A North Korea missile test spooked investors briefly, but they quickly shrugged off the latest provocation. FANG internet giants were strong while Biogen (BIIB) and Bluebird Bio (BLUE) were among the notable biotech breakouts. Construction materials and other stocks seen as benefiting from post-Harvey rebuilding and purchases rebounded.Over 3 million barrels per day of refining capacity, or 16% of total U.S. capacity, was offline due to Hurricane Harvey, according to S&P Global Platts, sending gasoline futures soaring to two-year highs. Refineries could be shut for several weeks. Gas Buddy said the national gasoline average jumped by over 11 cents per gallon from the prior week with more price hikes on the way. U.S. crude futures fell as fewer refiners were available to convert oil to gasoline and other products. U.S. crude inventories fell by 5.4 million barrels in the latest week with gasoline supplies flat, the Energy Information Administration reported, but that doesn't reflect Harvey's impact. Domestic production was essentially flat at 9.53 million barrels a day, still near the record high of 9.61 million reached in June 2015.Two days after Gilead Sciences (GILD) said it would pay $11.9 billion, or $180 a share, for Kite Pharma (KITE) and pivot to cellular therapies, Novartis (NVS) was the first to grab FDA approval for a CAR-T treatment. Kymriah was OK'd to treat a form of acute lymphoblastic leukemia in patients up to age 25. But Kite's drug is expected to be approved this fall to treat an aggressive form of non-Hodgkin lymphoma. Gilead soared 13.5% to a one-year high as Novartis' CAR-T approval appeared to validate its plan to acquire Kite, which shot up 28%. Drug giant Novartis climbed 0.3%. Other CAR-T players include Bluebird Bio (BLUE), which rose 34% to clear a buy point, and Juno Therapeutics (JUNO), which popped 36%. Both are partnered with Celgene (CELG), which gained 7.5% to edge past its own buy point.RELATED:Why Investors Are Mute On Gilead's Acquisition Of Kite PharmaAnalysts Mixed On Gilead-Kite, But One Key Rival Stands To BenefitNovartis' CAR-T Drug Win Helps Gilead To Spike Post Kite DealThe U.S. added just 159,000 jobs in August, fewer than expected, while June and July payroll growth was revised down. The jobless rate ticked up to 4.4%, vs. views for a steady 4.3%. But the ISM manufacturing index jumped to its best level in more than six years. Meanwhile, Q2 GDP growth was revised up to a 3% annual rate, the best in more than two years.RELATED:U.S. Adds Just 156,000 Jobs; August Jobless Rate Rises To 4.4%The takeover is complete. To mark Day One of its ownership of Whole Foods, the e-commerce titan discounted a number of produce, dairy and meat offerings at the upscale grocer, bringing down the prices of bananas, eggs, butter, several varieties of milk, fish and ground beef, among other things. Amazon Echos were also displayed prominently in Whole Foods stores. Amazon.com (AMZN) shares climbed 3.5%.General Motors (GM) reported a bigger-than-expected U.S. sales gain while Ford (F) sales fell less than expected, even though Hurricane Harvey likely cut Texas sales. Fiat Chrysler (FCAU) sales fell sharply, while Toyota (TM) missed views. With Harvey destroying some 300,000 to 1 million vehicles, auto sales and pricing may get a boost. Shares of automakers generally rallied, with GM breaking out past a buy point Friday.Consumer electronics retailer Best Buy (BBY) topped fiscal second-quarter estimates and guided higher for the current quarter and full year. Q2 same-store sales rose 5.4% vs. views for 2.2%. But Best Buy CEO Hubert Joly cautioned them not to expect recent gains to be the "new normal." Best Buy has gained business recently from struggling Sears (SHLD) and bankrupt HHGregg, but is likely to face tougher competition from Amazon.com (AMZN) in the holiday quarter. Best Buy crashed nearly 12%, tumbling below its buy point.Ciena (CIEN) topped views for fiscal third-quarter sales and earnings. But for its fiscal fourth quarter, the fiber-optic network supplier expects adjusted earnings to rise 14% to 50 cents a share, on a sales increase of 3% to $735 million, based on the midpoint of its guidance. Wall Street was modeling for 58 cents and $770 million. The soft guidance was a shocker, given Ciena's previously bullish stance, Nomura Instinet said. Ciena tumbled 11% on Thursday.Workday (WDAY) reported second-quarter earnings of 24 cents a share, trouncing the estimate for 15 cents. Revenue rose 41% to $525.3 million, ahead of the consensus estimate of $506.9 million. The cloud-based human resources and finance software firm raised its full-year subscription revenue forecast.Workday shares rose 5.1% to their best levels since early 2014.Box reported second-quarter earnings that beat estimates on the top and bottom lines. Revenue rose 28% to $122.9 million, beating the consensus estimate of $122 million. Adjusted earnings of an 11-cent loss beat the consensus estimate of a 13-cent loss. Box shares fell 2.7% for the week.RELATED:Box Second-Quarter Revenue And Earnings Top ViewsNew CEO Dara Khosrowshahi promised changes to take the ride-sharing pioneer to the next level and set an IPO timeline of 18 to 36 months. Khosrowshahi came to Uber from Expedia (EXPE). The travel booking site's CFO Mark Okerstrom took the CEO reins on Khosrowshahi's departure. Uber's board took more than two months to settle on a new chief, following the exit of co-founder and former CEO Travis Kalanick amid accusations of discrimination, sexual harassment and mismanagement.Finish Line (FINL) crashed nearly 17%, hitting an 8-year low during the week, after the sporting goods retailer slashed its full-year profit and same-store sales outlook, saying that the athletic footwear business "became much more promotional" over the second quarter. The forecast followed weak quarterly showings from Foot Locker (FL), Dick's Sporting Goods (DKS) and Hibbett Sports (HIBB). The news follows the retail sector's struggles with online shopping and this summer's agreement between Amazon and Nike (NKE), in which the shoemaker would test out the sale of some products directly on Amazon. Nike and Under Armour (UAA) shares fell sharply.The teen-centric discount retailer's second-quarter results beat estimates, with Five Below (FIVE) citing a continued "notable contribution from the spinner trend," and it hiked its full-year outlook. Value retailer Ollie's Bargain Outlet (OLLI) also beat Q2 estimates and raised its outlook. Dollar General (DG) revenue and same-store sales beat, but its Q2 EPS and higher full-year profit outlook missed expectations. Shares of all three specialty discounters fell significantly for the week.Wells Fargo (WFC) hiked the number of unauthorized customer accounts by 1.4 million, or 67%, to 3.5 million, after a review expanded the time period covered.Otonomy (OTIC) crashed 83% to an all-time low Wednesday after its drug to treat an inner-ear disease failed in a Phase 3 trial.Analog Devices (ADI) reported fiscal third-quarter sales and earnings that easily beat views. The chipmaker also sees current Q4 EPS up 30% and sales rising 50% to $1.5 billion, at the midpoint of its guidance, both higher than Wall Street models. Analog Devices rose nearly 7%.Shares of J. Jill (JILL) fell 10.1%, hitting record lows during the week, after the women's apparel retailer offered up disappointing Q3 and full-year guidance. Q2 adjusted EPS rose 21%, in line with views. Sales grew 9.9% to $181.4 million vs. estimates for $179.1 million.Lululemon Athletica (LULU) reported surprise profit growth of 3% to an adjusted 39 cents a share, on revenue of $581.1 million, better than estimates for 35 cents EPS and $568 million in sales. The yogawear maker and retailer's same-store sales rose 7%, well above estimates for 4%. Shares jumped 7.2% on Friday.

The stock market was its normal, resilient self Tuesday as the Nasdaq composite turned a 0.9% intraday loss into a gain of 0.3% by the close. Even better, the Nasdaq reclaimed its 50-day moving average.Sentiment turned negative quickly late Monday and early Tuesday on news that North Korea fired another missile, this time over Japan, but major stock indexes ended with decent gains.XThe Dow Jones industrial average added 0.3% and the S&P 500 picked up 0.1%. Preliminary data showed volume on the NYSE and Nasdaq coming in about 10% higher than Monday's levels.The bond market saw more buying, sending the 10-year Treasury yield lower by 3 basis points to 2.13%. The yield hasn't been this low since November. The takeaway? If interest rates are indeed headed higher, the bond market isn't buying it.United Technologies (UTX) outperformed in the Dow, rising nearly 3%, on a report that the company is close to consummating a deal with Rockwell Collins (COL) that could be worth north of $20 billion. Shares of Rockwell Collins rose 0.5%Also in the Dow, Nike slumped 2%, hurt by news from Finish Line (FINL). Finish Line shares crashed 18% after the company slashed its full-year profit and same-store sales outlook, citing weakening sales and margin trends. Shares of Foot Locker (FL), Hibbett Sports (HIBB) and Dick's Sporting Goods (DKS) have been lagging badly after reporting weak earnings earlier in the month.In the stock market today, Catalent (CTLT) gapped up on strong earnings, surging 14% to 40.27. The move put the stock near the top of a 5% buy zone from a 38.83 entry. The company provides drug delivery technology and development solutions for biotech and pharmaceutical firms.Gold rallied again but ended well off session highs. SPDR Gold Shares (GLD) hit an intraday high of 125.87, up 0.9%, but ended down 0.2% to 124.42. The highly liquid exchange traded fund is still in buy range from a 123.41 entry, although Tuesday's reversal is not what you want to see so soon after a breakout.Meanwhile, the market's initial response to Best Buy's (BBY) earnings was positive, but enthusiasm was short-lived as shares crashed 12%.Sales at Best Buy rose 5% from the year-ago quarter to $8.94 billion, the best quarterly sales growth in at least five years for the electronics retailer. The company cited strong sales in computing, wearables, smart-home devices, mobile phones and appliances.Best Buy had been holding above a 59.79 double-bottom entry, but the stock fell more than 7% below the buy point, triggering an IBD sell rule that says to cut losses in a stock at 7%-8%.Inside the IBD 50, China-based stocks rebounded after rough sessions Monday. TAL Education (TAL), New Oriental Education (EDU) and Autohome (ATHM) showed gains ranging from 1% to 4%.After the close, watch for earnings from Ollie's Bargain Outlet (OLLI). The stock is still holding above the 50-day moving average, but it's been getting resistance near 45 after a breakout over a 44.17 buy point. Shares fell 1% to 43.30 ahead of the results.RELATED:Best Buy Crushes On Earnings, But CEO Puts A Chill On SharesPalo Alto Networks Expected To Maintain Double-Digit Growth Report: United Technologies In $20 Billion-Plus Deal For Rockwell CollinsOllie's Bargain Outlet Is Just Below A Buy Point With Q2 Earnings Due

Stocks opened sharply lower Tuesday as a North Korean missile firing sent global stocks lower and, in the U.S., the shutdown of Houston continued as Tropical Storm Harvey crept north into Louisiana.X The Dow Jones industrial average and S&P 500 skidded 0.5% lower at the starting bell. The Nasdaq Composite tumbled 0.7%.Japan and South Korea went on high alert Tuesday, after a ballistic missile launched by North Korea flew over the north Japanese island of Hokkaido and another 700 miles before crashing into the Pacific. The launch sent Hokkaido residents scrambling to take shelter, and stirred condemnation among world leaders.Tokyo's Nikkei 225 ended 0.5% lower. Hong Kong's Hang Seng index tumbled 0.4%, and currencies went into a frenzy of risk-off trade. Europe's markets traded down sharply in their afternoon session, with Frankfurt's DAX down 1.9%, the CAC-40 in Paris off 1.3% and London's FTSE 100 down 1.1%.Meanwhile, Harvey had moved back out into the U.S. Gulf of Mexico and began to edge north, but continued to dump more than 1 inch per hour of rain Houston on Tuesday, according to the Houston Chronicle, which also reported power outages across the city with no access yet possible for utility repair crews.Oil future traded down 0.3% and gasoline futures jumped 1.4 early Tuesday, as Texas refiners and oil producers remained hunkered down due to weather.  About 2.2 million barrels per day of refining capcity is reported shut down from companies including Exxon Mobil (XOM), Royal Dutch Shell (RDSA), Valero (VLO) and Phillips 66 (PSX), while Marathon Petroleum (MPC) and LyondellBasell (LYB) reported partial shutdowns.A smaller portion of operations were closed in Texas' Eagle Ford shale production area, with Bentek Energy reporting about 5% of expected output was shut early Tuesday.Airports also remained closed in Houston with the Federal Aviation Administration projecting the closures would last until at least Aug. 30. Bush Intercontinental Airport is the second busiest airport for United Continental Holdings (UAL). Houston's Hobby Airport is an important hub for Southwest Airlines (LUV).Dow stocks traded almost unanimously lower. Nike (NKE) led the downside, dragged down 2.1% by a profit warning from retailer Finish Line (FINL).  Finish Line — a non-Dow stock — collapsed 25% in opening trade, after preliminary results guided Q2 EPS to half the number expected by consensus views, and following a downgrade to neutral, from buy, by FBR Capital. Foot Locker (FL) also felt some of the downdraft, trading 2% lower at the open.Best Buy (BBY) dived 8% at the open, despite scoring a broad second-quarter win. Athletic apparel chain Finish Line's (FINL) acquisition by U.K. retail giant JD Sports may benefit Nike (NKE), Adidas (ADDYY) and Under Armour (UAA), while creating a savvy new threat to Foot Locker (FL), analysts say.XHaving expanded overseas in recent years, entering markets like France, Spain and South Korea, JD Sports had been eyeing an entry into the U.S., and the $558 million Finish Line deal announced Monday will bring the British firm's expertise in operating successful sportswear outlets to the lucrative market.And as prices for athletic gear have been hit by the highly competitive environment lately, companies like Nike could see an improvement with JD in the U.S."Having JD operate the Finish Line stores could strengthen the overall operating performance, thus providing incremental full-priced selling opportunities for the brands especially if JD were to accelerate U.S. store openings of its own banner and the remodeling of FINL stores," said Baird Equity Research senior analyst Jonathan Komp in a note.The JD takeover also means Foot Locker will face a more formidable global competitor operating in its home market, Komp added."Note that JD also indicated plans to open a number of JD branded stores in the U.S. and to accelerate reimaging of the Finish Line store fleet, both of which may be competitive threats for FL," he pointed out.B. Riley FBR senior analyst Susan Anderson believes the deal will give Finish Line better access to high-end products.And while there may be short-term benefits for Foot Locker, as JD Sports intends to follow through with Finish Line's plans to close under-performing stores, in the long run it could create a stronger company that will be more of a threat, she added.Shares of Finish Line soared 31% to close at 13.83 on the stock market today, topping JD Sports' per-share takeover price of 13.50. Nike climbed 2%, Under Armour jump 5.6% and Adidas gained 1.6%. Foot Locker advanced 3.5%.Get these newsletters delivered to your inbox & more info about our products & services. Privacy Policy & Terms of UseFinish Line operates around 950 branded locations in U.S. malls and shops inside Macy's department stores, and employs more than 14,000 people. The firm's revenue in the year to March 3, 2018, was $1.84 billion."With JD, Finish Line achieves immediate value for its shareholders and moves into a stronger position to compete as part of a global enterprise that leads in our industry," said Bill Carmichael, lead director of the Finish Line board.YOU MAY ALSO BE INTERESTED IN:Why Nike Is 'Back In Business' In North America After Sales Slump Yeezy Does It: Nordstrom Teams Up With Rare-Sneaker SpecialistTwo Nike Execs Step Down Amid Reports Of Misconduct ProbeStill Bullish On Bitcoin? Stock futures pointed to solid early gains Friday, after banks received a positive report card from the Federal Reserve and Nike (NKE) swooshed higher after its fiscal fourth-quarter report.Other hot performers in Friday's premarket session included JPMorgan (JPM), KB Home (KBH) and Wells Fargo (WFC).Despite Thursday's rebound, the major indexes were down for the week. Instead, the Fed held the banks' payouts to levels from prior years, saying that the companies, in effect, needed to save more money.Wells Fargo shares received the largest boost among big banks from the Fed's stress-test report. As a result, the company late Thursday raised its quarterly dividend to 43 cents from 39 cents, and announced plans to throw an additional $15 billion into its share-buyback program. The increasingly saturated sportswear market and rival Adidas' (ADDYY) emergence as a market-share-munching contender have rattled Nike (NKE) recently, but the Swoosh insists that its fortunes are turning in the U.S. — and some analysts are inclined to agree.Nike topped overall forecasts, but its holiday-quarter performance in North America still reflected a 6% revenue decline, marking the third consecutive drop in the crucial market. By contrast, Adidas' North America sales surged 31% in its most recently reported quarter.But Nike sees revenue on its home turf coming in flat in the current fiscal Q4, then returning to growth in the following two quarters.Chief Executive Mark Parker expects a "reversal of trend" in Q4 in the U.S. and Canada, and called out the success of certain footwear styles, such as the Epic React, AirMax 270 and Vapormax. The end of fiscal Q3 marked a "significant turn" in North America as Nike focuses on hawking its products in certain retailers and offering digital shopper experiences, he added.Andy Campion, Nike's chief financial officer, said the slide was in line with its expectations as it tightens Jordan brand distribution and pulls back from what it calls "undifferentiated wholesale" outlets.Management sees total revenue rising by high single digits in Q4, in line with analyst consensus for 8% revenue growth."While Adidas' robust pace of share gains in the U.S. has posed a considerable headwind for (Nike) over the last year, we now see this abating, as NKE regains its brand heat and growth in (North America) re-accelerates," wrote Jefferies retail analyst Randal Konik in a Friday note, saying Nike U.S. is "back in business."Nike shares closed up 0.3% at 64.63 on the stock market today after rising as much as 4.3% earlier in the day and 7% after hours on Thursday. Rival Under Armour (UAA) edged up 0.3% and Adidas dipped 0.7%, while retailers Foot Locker (FL) and Finish Line (FINL) jumped 4.4% and 6.6%, respectively.Get these newsletters delivered to your inbox & more info about our products & services. Privacy Policy & Terms of UseMeanwhile, Nike is launching its app at retail in flagship stores in certain major North American cities, and said that its launch of Nike+ membership in the region, plus a digital push abroad, helped drive 18% growth in Nike.com revenue.The company has also ramped up its speed of delivery in certain cities, said Parker.But Nike's guidance for flat growth in North America still falls short of the Street's consensus for a return to growth in the current quarter.And the company is also grappling with a misconduct scandal and the exits of two high-level executives, including Nike Brand President Trevor Edwards, who will officially retire in August."We became aware of some behavioral issues that are inconsistent with Nike's values of inclusivity, respect and empowerment," said Parker on the call. "I'm committed to ensuring that we have an environment where every Nike employee can have a positive experience and reach their full potential."YOU MIGHT BE INTERESTED IN: Nike Rival Adidas Says This 'Massive Category' Is Growing The FastestAdd These 6 Top-Rated Apparel Stocks To Your Watch List WardrobeYeezy Does It: Nordstrom Teams Up With Rare-Sneaker SpecialistTwo Nike Execs Step Down Amid Reports Of Misconduct ProbeAdidas' U.S. Boss Talks Amazon, Retail Strategies, And Kanye's Real Impact

Nike (NKE) topped fiscal Q3 forecasts after the close Thursday and signaled a recent sales slump in North America is ending, helping offset fears of a trade war sparked by President Trump's tariffs.Estimates: A 23.5% slide to 52 cents in per-share profit. Analysts see revenue rising 4.9% to $8.84 billion, according to Zacks Investment Research.Results: EPS of 68 cents, excluding tax-related charges, on revenue of $8.98 billion. North America revenue fell 6% to $3.57 billion with apparel flat and footwear down 8%. Europe, Middle East and Africa revenue jumped 19% to $2.3 billion. Greater China revenue surged 24% to $1.34 billion. Asia Pacific and Latin America revenue grew 13% to $1.27 billion."Nike's Consumer Direct Offense drove strong double-digit growth across our international geographies, led by Greater China," said Chairman and CEO Mark Parker in a statement. "As we close Q3, we now see a significant reversal of trend in North America, as momentum accelerates through the scaling of new innovation platforms and differentiated NIKE Consumer Experiences expand across the marketplace."Stock: Nike jumped 7.1% late. Shares closed down 2.9% at 64.42 on the stock market today, breaching their 50-day moving average as the Trump administration unveiled tariffs against China, which has been a top growth driver for Nike. Rival Under Armour (UAA) fell 1.4%. Major Nike retailer Foot Locker (FL) sank 4.3%.Get these newsletters delivered to your inbox & more info about our products & services. Privacy Policy & Terms of UseNorth America revenue has been in focus, as  sales have slumped while rival Adidas (ADDYY) has been gaining share on Nike's home turf and turned in double-digit growth during the holiday quarter.Adidas North America chief Mark King told Investor's Business Daily last week that its growth in the family channel — at stores such as Kohl's (KSS) and DSW (DSW) — and at Dick's Sporting Goods (DKS), where its training apparel is sold, are strong.But Nike's continued strong performance in China also underscores a vulnerability as Trump has directed relatively heavy economic fire toward China. Nike has echoed concerns from trade groups representing Walmart (WMT), Apple (AAPL), Best Buy (BBY) and other retailers warning that tariffs would raise prices for American consumers.Meanwhile, CEO Parker must grapple with other recent headlines. An informal survey about inappropriate behavior had been circulated by female Nike employees, reported the Wall Street Journal earlier in the week.The news followed the resignation of No. 2 executive and Nike Brand President Trevor Edwards and the exit of exec Jayme Martin, who was forced out amid complaints of misconduct. YOU MIGHT BE INTERESTED IN: Add These 6 Top-Rated Apparel Stocks To Your Watch List WardrobeYeezy Does It: Nordstrom Teams Up With Rare-Sneaker SpecialistTwo Nike Execs Step Down Amid Reports Of Misconduct Probe

Airline stocks outperformed in the stock market today as oil prices plunged. Meanwhile, homebuilders outperformed as the 10-year Treasury yield fell further below the 3% level. It was trading around 2.93%, down another 5 basis points, after hitting a high of 3.11% on May 17.Selling was contained in the stock market today as the Dow Jones industrial average and S&P 500 eased 0.3%. The Nasdaq composite edged higher by 0.1%. Volume on the NYSE and Nasdaq was tracking lower than Thursday's levels ahead of the three-day weekend. The stock market will be closed Monday in observance of Memorial Day.The airline group was up nearly 3% in late trading. Strong performers in the group included Spirit Airlines (SAVE), Alaska Air (ALK), Southwest Airlines (LUV) and American Airlines (AAL) with gains of 3% to 4%. Airline stocks have been on lengthy downtrends.Homebuilders also outperformed amid falling interest rates, but like the airline stocks, they been hit hard by selling in recent months as well. Lennar (LEN) was a top gainer in the group, rising about 4%.Inside the IBD 50, WildHorse Resource  Development (WRD) took a hit along with many other oil and gas names, falling 5%. U.S. crude oil futures settled at $67.88 a barrel, down 4%, after Saudi Arabia talked about higher output in the second half of the year. Oil and gas-related industry groups were among the hardest hit Friday, with losses ranging from 2% to 5%.Sector Leader Diamondback Energy (FANG) looked poised to extend its losing streak to four sessions. Shares slumped 4% after crashing 8.6% in the prior three sessions. Recent signs of institutional selling in the fast-growth oil and gas producer knocked its Accumulation/Distribution Rating down to D-.In stock market results today, earnings reports dominated the headlines again.Splunk (SPLK) lost nearly 5% despite reporting its third straight quarter of 30%-plus ales growth. Another top-performing software stock, Veeva Systems (VEEV), reversed lower despite strong results.In the retail space, earnings losers had the upper hand over gainers, but Foot Locker (FL) was a bright spot. Shares gapped and rose 20% to 55.53 in late trading. It cleared a bottoming base with a conventional entry at 53.27.On the downside, Ross Stores (ROST) gapped below the 50-day moving average, falling 7%, after its outlook disappointed. Meanwhile, shares of The Gap (GPS) plunged 13%, after same-store sales fell more than expected.RELATED:Cloud Computing: Find Top Cloud Stocks And Track Industry TrendsThe Warning Signs Were There For This Former Leading Oil StockTech, Retail Elite To Report; Jobs Data: Investing Action Plan
