Stocks fell hard yesterday, as energy names got clobbered; Spdr Energy  (XLE) -3% because oil came under new pressure - breaking $40/barrel sending the algo's into a tailspin, Utilities under the gun; Spdr Utilities  (XLU) - 2.3% on the prospect of the coming rate hike, the dollar showing strength  because of that same rate hike all causing the broader mkt to come under pressure.

Toss in the speech that Yellen gave yesterday at the Economic Club of Washington and you have the perfect recipe for disaster.....First of all....I have to ask - Why does the media find it so important to broadcast a speech that Yellen is giving to a local Economic club?

[Their own home page says it like this: The Economic Club of Washington, D.C., has, since its founding, played a vital role in shifting the perception of Washington, D.C., from a focus on the city as the center of our national government to a growing awareness of the region as a global business destination] Now yes....it is a Washington DC club and has access to so many people - BUT it is NOT national policy, it is NOT where FED decisions are made, and it is NOT the FED....it's a local club...... So - This was NOT an FOMC speech, it was NOT a formal policy speech, it was NOT a press conference...in fact all it was - was a scheduled speech delivered by the FED Chair.....ok...I get it, She is the FED chair.....but in the end who cares?  Why does this matter when she is just giving a prepared speech to a group of economists (well educated but none of which will influence policy) .....

Did anyone think she was making 'the announcement'?   This was NOT an announcement about new monetary/economic policy....it was just more of the same.....hash and re-hash...because in the end she played both sides of the fence leaving it open to speculation/interpretation and conjecture - for WHAT?  Is this not clear? “On balance, economic and financial information received since our October meeting has been consistent with our expectations of continued improvement in the labor market,” Ms. Yellen said in her speech. “Continuing improvement in the labor market helps strengthen confidence that inflation will move back to our 2% objective over the medium term.”.......She went further and said:

“Were the [Fed] to delay the start of policy normalization for too long, we would likely end up having to tighten policy relatively abruptly to keep the economy from significantly overshooting both of our goals,” she said. “Such an abrupt tightening would risk disrupting financial markets and perhaps even inadvertently push the economy into recession. Moreover, holding the federal funds rate at its current level for too long could also encourage excessive risk-taking and thus undermine financial stability.”  The longer she spoke the worse it got....the Twitter sphere, the business news channels offering up min by min analysis.....what did that word mean?  What did that sentence mean?  Did you see the look on her face - surely that must mean that rates are not going to rise or maybe she is just playing us....????  Blah, blah, blah....and so we have more of the same.  And today we get to do it all again as Janet now addresses the Jt Economic Committee of Congress....expect more of the same again......it's exhausting really......all this transparency is BS......In the end - she made it clear that she is ready.....enough of the foreplay......let's get to it!

This was clear in what she said about possible dissension in the ranks - which some expect will only complicate her position....“I don’t need unanimity. I think we have to tolerate some dissent,” Ms. Yellen said Wednesday, in answer to a question after delivering a speech on the economic outlook. “I wouldn’t try to stifle dissents, and I would even expect some at critical junctures.”

And there it is.....she just laid it out...SHE DOES NEED UNANIMITY.... and chiming in from FL - was Atlanta FED pres Lockhart.....saying: “Absent information that drastically changes the economic picture and outlook, I feel the case for liftoff is compelling"

Now back to OIL.... We have been talking about the importance of paying attention to the oil market for a long time now....as this is so crucial in understanding the dynamics at play.... Oil prices fell below $40 a barrel yesterday amid this growing global glut which only puts  more pressure on an industry that already is already bleeding....Yesterday we got a report that signaled the 10th straight weekly rise in U.S. inventories of crude oil at a time of year when they are expected to shrink.....but the real problem is global production......as  OPEC, the U.S. and other non OPEC members  are locked in a battle for market share that has left the world flooded with oil.  This will all come to a head tomorrow...at the OPEC meeting...what will the Saudi's do?  Will they play nice in the sand box?  Doubtful....so oil will almost certainly remain under pressure.... which will continue to put pressure on the energy space......and until we see total capitulation we have not seen the bottom....but it feels like we are one step closer to the 'flush'.  There is plenty of room for crude oil prices to continue to collapse, based on this chart — given that support has now been violated.   $30/barrel is not out of the question at this point... and given that rising rates will only further strengthen in the dollar - is that what  the Fed wants, perhaps believing that if gas prices collapse then that could actually help the economy?  This morning - the humans got to re-think all the noise - and realized that the action created by the algo's yesterday was ridiculous....the mkt and investors are now conditioned to accept a 25 bps hike... but they are also keen on going slow in the new year....and that is exactly what Janet intimated yesterday.....and so after  the  selloff yesterday - US futures are up 10 pts at 2092.........volleying between 2065 and 2100.....Does this sound like a broken record? Eco data today includes Challenger Job Cuts - came in at -13.9% which is a positive number - because it says that job losses were 13.9% lower than last year...... We will also get US Services PMI at 56.5, and ISM Non Manf Composite read of 58.  Factory orders to show a gain of 1.4%. European mkts are all higher as they await the Draghi news conference and announcement...the chatter in Europe is that he has to deliver something really BIG....More Park Sausages, MOM!!!  If he fails to deliver that then look for  a selloff  - but I do not believe that will happen...  Here comes Santa Clause....the FTSE+0.12%, CAC 40 +1.07%, DAX  +0.68%, Eurostoxx +1%, Spain +0.86% and Italy +1.13%. Take good care —  Kp

for WHAT?  Is this not clear? “On balance, economic and financial information received since our October meeting has been consistent with our expectations of continued improvement in the labor market,” Ms. Yellen said in her speech. “Continuing improvement in the labor market helps strengthen confidence that inflation will move back to our 2% objective over the medium term.”.......She went further and said:“Were the [Fed] to delay the start of policy normalization for too long, we would likely end up having to tighten policy relatively abruptly to keep the economy from significantly overshooting both of our goals,” she said. “Such an abrupt tightening would risk disrupting financial markets and perhaps even inadvertently push the economy into recession. Moreover, holding the federal funds rate at its current level for too long could also encourage excessive risk-taking and thus undermine financial stability.”  The longer she spoke the worse it got....the Twitter sphere, the business news channels offering up min by min analysis.....what did that word mean?  What did that sentence mean?  Did you see the look on her face - surely that must mean that rates are not going to rise or maybe she is just playing us....????  Blah, blah, blah....and so we have more of the same.  And today we get to do it all again as Janet now addresses the Jt Economic Committee of Congress....expect more of the same again......it's exhausting really......all this transparency is BS......In the end - she made it clear that she is ready.....enough of the foreplay......let's get to it!This was clear in what she said about possible dissension in the ranks - which some expect will only complicate her position....“I don’t need unanimity. I think we have to tolerate some dissent,” Ms. Yellen said Wednesday, in answer to a question after delivering a speech on the economic outlook. “I wouldn’t try to stifle dissents, and I would even expect some at critical junctures.”And there it is.....she just laid it out...SHE DOES NEED UNANIMITY.... and chiming in from FL - was Atlanta FED pres Lockhart.....saying: “Absent information that drastically changes the economic picture and outlook, I feel the case for liftoff is compelling"Now back to OIL.... We have been talking about the importance of paying attention to the oil market for a long time now....as this is so crucial in understanding the dynamics at play.... Oil prices fell below $40 a barrel yesterday amid this growing global glut which only puts  more pressure on an industry that already is already bleeding....Yesterday we got a report that signaled the 10th straight weekly rise in U.S. inventories of crude oil at a time of year when they are expected to shrink.....but the real problem is global production......as  OPEC, the U.S. and other non OPEC members  are locked in a battle for market share that has left the world flooded with oil.  This will all come to a head tomorrow...at the OPEC meeting...what will the Saudi's do?  Will they play nice in the sand box?  Doubtful....so oil will almost certainly remain under pressure.... which will continue to put pressure on the energy space......and until we see total capitulation we have not seen the bottom....but it feels like we are one step closer to the 'flush'.  There is plenty of room for crude oil prices to continue to collapse, based on this chart — given that support has now been violated.   $30/barrel is not out of the question at this point... and given that rising rates will only further strengthen in the dollar - is that what  the Fed wants, perhaps believing that if gas prices collapse then that could actually help the economy?  This morning - the humans got to re-think all the noise - and realized that the action created by the algo's yesterday was ridiculous....the mkt and investors are now conditioned to accept a 25 bps hike... but they are also keen on going slow in the new year....and that is exactly what Janet intimated yesterday.....and so after  the  selloff yesterday - US futures are up 10 pts at 2092.........volleying between 2065 and 2100.....Does this sound like a broken record? Eco data today includes Challenger Job Cuts - came in at -13.9% which is a positive number - because it says that job losses were 13.9% lower than last year...... We will also get US Services PMI at 56.5, and ISM Non Manf Composite read of 58.  Factory orders to show a gain of 1.4%. European mkts are all higher as they await the Draghi news conference and announcement...the chatter in Europe is that he has to deliver something really BIG....More Park Sausages, MOM!!!  If he fails to deliver that then look for  a selloff  - but I do not believe that will happen...  Here comes Santa Clause....the FTSE+0.12%, CAC 40 +1.07%, DAX  +0.68%, Eurostoxx +1%, Spain +0.86% and Italy +1.13%. Take good care —  Kp Kenny Polcari is Vice President and director of NYSE Floor Operations on behalf of O’Neil Securities, Inc., a sister company of Investor's Business Daily. Never mind "Let It Snow." Heading into the crucial holiday shopping season, retailers are more likely singing "Let It Go" from the movie "Frozen" as they try to shake off disappointing quarterly earnings results and a bad week that collectively sank merchant stocks.Nordstrom (JWN), Macy 's (M), J.C. Penney Co. (JCP) and Kohl's (KSS) were among those that reported the week of Nov. 9, with Nordstrom and Macy's turning in weak results and discounted forecasts, and J.C. Penney and Kohl's shares falling despite beating consensus views.An October retail sales data miss — a worse-than-expected 0.1% gain — didn't help either, though Amazon (AMZN) and other e-commerce sellers notably logged a 7.1% rise from the previous year as consumers continue to do much of their shopping online. Cowen & Co. predicted in July that Amazon would knock out Macy's as the top U.S. apparel retailer by 2017.Even much-lauded off-pricers haven't been immune to the pummeling that retail stocks were subjected to over the past week. Shares of TJX (TJX), the parent company of T.J. Maxx, Marshalls and HomeGoods, lost 12% over the past week.In a possible sign of things to come, Q3 same-store sales at Nordstrom's off-price arm, Nordstrom Rack, fell 2.2%."This type of miss from Rack is surprising to us, and we acknowledge the Rack's off-price slowdown could be a negative indicator for TJX," wrote Cowen & Co. analyst Oliver Chen on Friday.But he added that TJX, which reports Tuesday, could "offset some secular weakness" based on a few factors, including the strength of the company's sourcing and buying teams, home goods offerings and international reach.The company is expected to report a slight earnings dip of 1% to 84 cents a share. That would mark the third straight quarter of earnings deceleration and a swing from earnings gains of 7%, 8% and 15% in the three preceding periods.Revenue is seen rising 5% to $7.73 million, which also would reflect a slowdown.With a 75 IBD Composite Rating, TJX is the highest ranking member of IBD's Retail-Apparel/Shoes/Accessories group, which ranks a feeble 144 out of 197 groups.Peers in the group include Ross Stores, Foot Locker (FL), L Brands (LB) and American Eagle Outfitters (AEO).Fellow off-pricer Ross Stores (ROST) gapped down ahead of its Thursday earnings release, losing 11% for the week. Analysts expect over 6% EPS growth to 50 cents on 6% sales growth to $2.77 billion.And what about the big-box retailers?Target's (TGT) earnings are seen accelerating, with a predicted 59% climb to 86 cents a share on a 1% revenue dip to $17.57 billion. Shares retreated 6.9% last week.And Wall Street expects Wal-Mart (WMT) earnings to slide 15% to 98 cents a share on a 1% revenue decline to $117.79 billion. Shares slid 4%."We believe retail is in a state of transition as brands wrestle with how to compete against growing & dynamic pureplay online retailers," wrote Chen.RELATED:Retail Sales Weak, Except For Amazon, EcommerceMacy's Stock Selloff Could Be Tip Of Iceberg4 Reasons TJX, Off-Price Retailers Will Keep Surging.

The stock market's pullback extended another session Wednesday. Yet despite a disappointing reversal for all the major indexes, the decline did not disturb the overall uptrend. The Nasdaq composite wasted an early 0.5% gain to end down 0.3%. The S&P 500 also fell 0.3%. Volume declined. Small caps fell harder. The S&P 600 was off 0.8%. In general, such reversals…

U.S. stocks showed hesitation Wednesday after the previous session's strong price gains. The Nasdaq slipped 0.4%, while the S&P 500 and the Dow Jones industrial average eased 0.3% and 0.2%, respectively. Volume in the stock market today dropped vs. Tuesday's already below-average pace.

Blue chips were mostly down. Only a handful of stocks in the Dow rose and those in tiny steps. On the downside, Chevron (CVX) carved off 1% in slow turnover as West Texas intermediate crude oil fell 3.5%. Chevron, an integrated oil company, has rebounded about 30% off its late August low but remains about 33% off its July 2014 high.

An integrated oil company is involved in many facets of the business: exploration, production, refining and distribution. From late June 2014, when crude oil began its fast price slide, the price of oil is now down 64%; U.S. explorers, down 63%; integrated, down 41%; and refiners, down 21%.

In the IBD 50 — a list of the best stocks in fundamentals and technicals — mortgage software provider Ellie Mae (ELLI) took the hardest hit, dropping more than 2%. But volume was about 20% below average.
Housing-related stocks got some bad news as November pending home sales dropped unexpectedly.

However, homebuilder D.R. Horton (DHI), a Leaderboard stock, shrugged the news off. Horton was down a penny in tepid volume.U.S. stocks showed hesitation Wednesday after the previous session's strong price gains. Major indexes scored big gains to close near session highs Friday, fueled by a raft of positive earnings surprises and overseas stimulus news.The Nasdaq rallied 2.3% while the S&P 500 rose 1.1% and the Dow Jones industrial average added 0.9%. Volume was mixed, running slightly lower on the NYSE and climbing on the Nasdaq, according to preliminary figures. All three indexes rose 2% or more for the week.Medical software, drugmaker and Internet stocks scored big gains in the stock market today, led by Amazon.com's (AMZN) 6% gap-up following its surprise Q3 profit late Thursday. Alphabet (GOOGL) gapped up and rose 6%, blowing past a 713.43 buy point, also after a Q3 beat.Apparel makers and retailers lagged.The two biggest Dow gainers were tech heavyweights that boosted the Nasdaq as well.Microsoft (MSFT) gapped up and surged 10% in heavy volume to its highest level in nearly 16 years. The software and Surface maker reported fiscal Q1 earnings and sales that trumped forecasts. RBC Capital Markets raised its price target Friday to 57 from 53.Apple (AAPL) rose 3% in light trade for its fourth up day this week. The stock has climbed well above its 50-day moving average and is trying to regain its 200-day line. Maxim Group upgraded the iPhone maker to buy from hold and raised its price target to 167 from 144. Apple reports Tuesday.In the IBD 50 , Manhattan Associates (MANH) gained 5% to a new high in brisk trade. It's well extended past a 65.63 handle buy point. Hawaiian (HA) lifted 4% to a record best , extending its win streak for a seventh session. The airline has soared 35% from a 25.69 buy point.But Foot Locker (FL) stumbled 8% in fast trade, undercutting its 200-day line for the first time since early February. Shoe-related stocks were mostly lower after Skechers (SKX) sank 32% following disappointing Q3 sales late Thursday.Global markets rallied as the European Central Bank indicated Thursday it would consider additional stimulus and China's central bank cut interest rates again. The Federal Reserve is widely expected to keep rates unchanged in the coming week.Economic data on tap for Monday include new-home sales for September and the Dallas Fed manufacturing survey for October.Follow Nancy Gondo on Twitter @IBD_NGondo.

The large-cap growth mutual fund's risk controls tend to prove themselves in volatile markets like the one that prevailed in August and September. Losing less for its investors than the broad market over the three months ended going into Tuesday, the fund topped 94% of its large-cap growth peers…
Toys R Us, the world's largest toy chain, plans to leave its flagship store in New York's Times Square as it faces an expected rent hike.

The 110,000-square-foot store at 1514 Broadway, with an indoor Ferris wheel and mechanical Tyrannosaurus Rex dinosaur, is too big for any single tenant, said C. Bradley Mendelson, vice chairman at Cushman & Wakefield, who is handling leasing for building-owner Bow Tie Partners. The landlord plans to break up the space, Mendelson said."The configuration of space is just too expensive for any one tenant," Mendelson said. "Market rates have changed substantially. It has nothing to do with Toys' ability. Toys has been a very good tenant for the last 15, 16 years."The move reflects rapid rent growth in the Times Square "bow tie" — the blocks immediately surrounding the area where Broadway and Seventh Avenue cross, often called the crossroads of the world. Retailers clamoring for access to the square's tourist traffic have been driving rents higher.Rates for ground-floor retail space in the bow tie area averaged $2,317 a square foot in late 2014, higher than anywhere in Manhattan except Fifth Avenue between 49th and 59th streets, according to a report by the Real Estate Board of New York. Three years earlier, the average was $1,433 a square foot.'Proud Resident'Toys R Us has been "a proud resident of Times Square since our international flagship store opened there," Linda Connors, a spokeswoman for the company, said in an emailed statement. "The lease for our store in Times Square expires in 2016 and, as previously noted, we have been reviewing our lease renewal options. We have not signed a lease agreement for a new location, and any rumors regarding this ongoing process are just that."The ground floor of 21,000 square feet is being marketed for $2,500 a square foot, its second-floor space for $350 a square foot, and the lower level at $150 a square foot, he said. There are four other retail tenants in the 150,000-square-foot building: Foot Locker (FL) and Swatch stores, a Starbucks (SBUX) coffee shop and the Bond 45 restaurant. Their leases all expire in February, the same time as Toys R Us, he said.Toys R Us may relocate to the retail storefronts across the square at the Marriott Marquis Hotel, where Vornado Realty Trust (VNO) controls the retail portion of the property, according to the Commercial Observer, which reported the retailer's move. Vornado, which owns a stake in the toy retailer, has installed Times Square's largest digital advertising sign above its stores.About 43,000 square feet of retail space are immediately available at the hotel, according to Vornado's website. Wendi Kopsick, a Vornado spokeswoman, said the company would have no comment.The model dinosaur and Ferris wheel are Toys R Us property, and could be used at its new store, "wherever that may be," Mendelson said. There have been discussions with Toys R Us about taking less space but "nothing ongoing right now" with the retailer, he said. The Times Square store was a staging area for marketing for the company, which has struggled in competition with the likes of Wal-Mart (WMT) and Amazon.com (AMZN).
Stocks put in strong gains Friday, thanks to a lower dollar and some well-received earnings reports.
The Dow Jones industrial average and the S&P 500 climbed 0.9% each. Meanwhile, the Nasdaq climbed 0.7%, closing back above the 5000 mark for the first time since March 2.
Volume swelled on both major exchanges in the stock market today due to quadruple witching.

In stocks, Ctrip.com International (CTRP) gapped up and surged 25% on late Thursday's better-than-expected fourth-quarter results and outlook. The stock gapped above its 50-day and 200-day moving averages.

Biogen Idec (BIIB) gapped up and rallied 10% in hefty trade following encouraging results from a study of its aducanumab Alzheimer's treatment. Biogen is far extended from a 347.85 buy point cleared in early December.

Nike (NKE) gapped up and rallied 4% despite reporting mixed fiscal Q3 results late Thursday. The athletic apparel and footwear giant's earnings topped views, but sales missed expectations due to a strong dollar. Canaccord Genuity lifted Nike's price target to 96 from 93 and maintained a hold rating. The stock opened above a 99.86 buy point from a flat base.
Foot Locker (FL), which is a big seller of Nike merchandise, rose 1%. It closed nearly 6% past a 59.29 buy point from a flat base cleared March 6.

On the downside, Vasco Data International (VDSI) slumped 5% after reversing lower. DSW (DSW) shares jumped to a 12-month high Tuesday after the shoe retailer stomped fourth-quarter earnings and sales estimates.

The Columbus, Ohio-based company earned 35 cents a share, a 13% gain from last year that marks a second quarter of acceleration. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters were expecting earnings to fall 10% to 28 cents a share. Revenue increased 12% to $640 million, above estimates for $612 million and a fourth straight quarter of faster growth.

DSW stock gapped up 4.7% to 38.57 on the stock market today in giant volume, clearing a 38.20 buy point from a flat base. Shares had edged above that level intraday on Feb. 24, but were trading tightly below the pivot since, until today.
During the quarter, DSW's comparable sales increased 7.6%, way above last year's flat comparable sales.
For the full year, DSW sees EPS of $1.80 to $1.90, or growth of 7% to 12%, which is on the weak side compared with Wall Street's $1.90 projection.
The company expects revenue growth of 7% to 8%, with comparable sales growth in the low- to mid-single-digit range. Analysts have calculated a 5.6% rise in revenue.
DSW says that it plans to open 35 new stores in 2015, including eight to 10 small-format stores.

The stock has an IBD Composite Rating of 75 out of 99, meaning its shares outperform 75% of all stocks in the market as measured by fundamental and technical factors. Some of those factors are earnings and sales growth, return on equity, profit margins and relative price performance.

The Retail-Apparel/Shoes/Accessories group is ranked No. 30 out of the 197 industry groups IBD tracks. The group is led by Ross Stores (ROST), Foot Locker (FL), Boot Barn (BOOT), Lululemon Athletica (LULU) and TJX (TJX).

Dick's Sporting Goods (DKS) scored points with investors after the retailer posted fourth-quarter profits and sales that crushed views on Tuesday morning, sending Dick's stock nearly 4% higher in early trading in the stock market today.
By early afternoon, shares were trading up just about half a percentage point from Monday's close, as the broader stock market pulled back following Monday's surge.

Dick's reported fourth-quarter earnings of $1.30 a share, up 17% from a year earlier. That handily beat the consensus forecast of analysts polled by Thomson Reuters for $1.22 a share. It followed a 2% rise in profits in the third quarter and marked the biggest quarterly profit gain for the sporting goods retailer since the fourth quarter of 2013.
Sales rose 11% to $2.160 billion, topping estimates for $2.118 billion. That followed a 9% increase in the third quarter and was the largest quarterly sales gain since the 2013 third quarter.

"The 17% increase in earnings per diluted share was driven by the continued growth of our omnichannel network, our powerful marketing and merchandising strategies, and the execution of these strategies by our store associates," said CEO Edward Stack in a press release.

Dick's struck a chord with shoppers during the competitive holiday period. Fourth-quarter consolidated same-store sales rose 3.4% vs. a year earlier. Same-store sales for Dick's Sporting Goods stores increased 3.8%, while its struggling Golf Galaxy stores saw same-store sales decline 7.1%.
E-commerce penetration for the fourth quarter was 14.4% of total sales vs. 12.2% in the fourth quarter of 2013.

Based on an estimated 120 million shares outstanding, the company expects first quarter earnings in the range of 49 cents to 53 cents a share. Analysts had forecast first-quarter earnings of 57 cents a share prior to Tuesday's report.
It estimates same-store sales for the first quarter will be flat to up 2%, compared to a 1.5% increase in the first quarter of 2014.

Based on an estimated 119 to 120 million shares outstanding, Dick's expects full-year earnings per share to fall between $3.10 and $3.20 a share. It expects full-year same-store sales to rise in the range of 1% to 3% vs. a year earlier, compared to a 2.4% increase in fiscal 2014.
Dick's is a part of IBD's Retail-Leisure Products industry group. It has a Composite Rating of 80 out of a possible 99.

Separately, athletic footwear and apparel retail operatorFoot Locker (FL) will report fourth-quarter financial results on March 6 before the market opens. That highly rated stock, with a 92 Composite Rating, is seen by analysts as one of the most important vendors of athletic shoes from Nike (NKE), which currently gets a 90 Composite Rating from IBD.Dick's Sporting Goods (DKS) scored points with investors after the retailer posted fourth-quarter profits and sales that crushed views on Tuesday morning, sending Dick's stock nearly 4% higher in early trading in the stock market today.By early afternoon, shares were trading up just about half a percentage point from Monday's close, as the broader stock market pulled back following Monday's surge.Dick's reported fourth-quarter earnings of $1.30 a share, up 17% from a year earlier. That handily beat the consensus forecast of analysts polled by Thomson Reuters for $1.22 a share. It followed a 2% rise in profits in the third quarter and marked the biggest quarterly profit gain for the sporting goods retailer since the fourth quarter of 2013.Sales rose 11% to $2.160 billion, topping estimates for $2.118 billion. That followed a 9% increase in the third quarter and was the largest quarterly sales gain since the 2013 third quarter."The 17% increase in earnings per diluted share was driven by the continued growth of our omnichannel network, our powerful marketing and merchandising strategies, and the execution of these strategies by our store associates," said CEO Edward Stack in a press release.Dick's struck a chord with shoppers during the competitive holiday period. Fourth-quarter consolidated same-store sales rose 3.4% vs. a year earlier. Same-store sales for Dick's Sporting Goods stores increased 3.8%, while its struggling Golf Galaxy stores saw same-store sales decline 7.1%.E-commerce penetration for the fourth quarter was 14.4% of total sales vs. 12.2% in the fourth quarter of 2013.Based on an estimated 120 million shares outstanding, the company expects first quarter earnings in the range of 49 cents to 53 cents a share. Analysts had forecast first-quarter earnings of 57 cents a share prior to Tuesday's report.It estimates same-store sales for the first quarter will be flat to up 2%, compared to a 1.5% increase in the first quarter of 2014.Based on an estimated 119 to 120 million shares outstanding, Dick's expects full-year earnings per share to fall between $3.10 and $3.20 a share. It expects full-year same-store sales to rise in the range of 1% to 3% vs. a year earlier, compared to a 2.4% increase in fiscal 2014.Dick's is a part of IBD's Retail-Leisure Products industry group. It has a Composite Rating of 80 out of a possible 99.Separately, athletic footwear and apparel retail operatorFoot Locker (FL) will report fourth-quarter financial results on March 6 before the market opens. That highly rated stock, with a 92 Composite Rating, is seen by analysts as one of the most important vendors of athletic shoes from Nike (NKE), which currently gets a 90 Composite Rating from IBD.

After a quiet start to the week, Thursday's new high list exploded thanks to solid gains for the major indexes. In Wednesday's session, about 45 stocks made the new-highs screen. The number tripled Thursday. A recent breakout for Ambarella (AMBA) is working nicely, but the stock closed near its low after early strength, falling 0.10 to 67.52. Its latest base…
The stock market is now back in a confirmed uptrend, and you know exactly what to do as an investor.

You have mastered how to quickly build a stock watch list. You recognize bullish chart patterns with ease. You know how to spot telltale signs that institutional investors are accumulating a stock. And you know when is the right time to buy a leading stock.
But what if the market spins its wheels again like it did in January 2015?

The Nasdaq composite finished last year at 4736. After a set of rapid sell-offs and rebounds, the index ended Feb. 6 at 4744, up slightly. Meanwhile, the Jan. 8 follow-through certainly has not yet revealed the same sort of strength that was seen in follow-through rallies in March 2009, September 2010 or late November 2012.

Last week's price gains were a welcome change for the bulls. But over the past year, stocks have shown their vulnerability to numerous corrections of 5% to 10%. A decline of that magnitude quickly erases solid gains even in the top dogs in your investment portfolio.
Do you have a game plan when the next rocky phase arrives?
The daily Investor's Corner column, in Wednesday's newspaper on B10, is the final part of a seven-story series to help you adjust your trading rules so that you avoid getting whipsawed.

The first story in this series, which ran in the Feb. 6 newspaper, defines a choppy stock market. All the stories note special rules and techniques to help you reduce your losses and nail down decent gains.

The stories give historical examples of how one could have bought and sold a leading stock effectively during a tough market. They include the case studies of Under Armour (UA) in 2014 and Foot Locker (FL). The Under Armour stock analysis was printed in the Feb. 10 newspaper and the Foot Locker stock performance review.

It never hurts to re-read a story that beefs up your stock trading skill and expands your knowledge of IBD buy and sell rules. You can always revisit them in the Investor's Corner archives. Go there by clicking on the IBD University tab on the home page of Investors.com.

Stock futures eased lower ahead of Friday's open, as the dollar gained and Q4 GDP data came in below expectations.Dow futures slipped 17.2 points below fair market value. S&P 500 futures were off 2.3 points. Nasdaq futures shifted from gains to a 1.5-point loss an hour before the start of regular trade.Stock Market TodayThe stock market today starts with the Nasdaq steering toward its worst week since October, down 3.2% through Thursday. The S&P 500 opens with a 2.5% loss for the week. Both indexes are testing support at their 50-day moving averages while toting a hefty count of seven distribution days each.The Nasdaq may be gathering itself to again challenge resistance at the 5000 level. But maintaining support at the 50-day line will be the crucial test on Friday.Economic NewsThe Commerce Department reported its estimate for Q4 GDP growth was 2.2%, unchanged from prior estimates, but below economist projections for an upward revision to 2.4%. The GDP price deflator inflation gauge held steady, up 0.1%, in line with expectations.A final reading on March consumer sentiment is expected from the University of Michigan at 10 a.m. ET. Fed Chairwoman Janet Yellen is scheduled to speak in San Francisco, beginning at 3:45 p.m. ET.StocksOlin (OLN) rocketed 20% higher on news that Dow Chemical (DOW) would merge its chlorine operations with Olin. The companies expect the deal, valued at $5 billion, to form an industry leader in chloralkali processing, producing vinyl, chlorinated organics and epoxy.Dow shares rose 6% in premarket trade. Olin had pulled back below a 15-month high after briefly clearing a long-term consolidation. Dow has been consolidating since September.Restoration Hardware (RH) slumped more than 4% ahead of the opening bell. The Corte Madera, Calif.-based chain reported late Thursday a narrow Q4 earnings beat and sales in line with expectations. Q1 guidance was below analyst targets. The stock has been forming a base-on-base cup, ending Thursday back above its 10-week line of support.Yahoo (YHOO) added nearly 2% after its late Thursday announcement of a $2 billion share buyback initiative. The company reported the new program was in addition to the $726 million in buybacks still active under its previous plan.Morgan Stanley launched coverage on the stock with an overweight rating and a 55 price target. Yahoo shares have been working to retake their 10-week moving average, within a four-month consolidation.OverseasChina's markets ended relatively flat on Friday after a week that left the Shanghai Composite up 2% and Hong Kong's Hang Seng index with a 2.7% gain. Tokyo's Nikkei 225 dipped 1% on Friday to end the week little changed.Leading indexes in Paris and Frankfurt were up nearly 1%. London's FTSE 100 showed a 0.3% loss near midday. For the week, the CAC-40 in Paris and Frankfurt's DAX were tracking toward 1% losses. The FTSE 100 traded 2.1% below last Friday's close.Currencies/CommoditiesThe dollar gained on the yen and sent the euro back below 1.09. Oil pulled back, almost 2% for the U.S. benchmark West Texas Intermediate crude, to below $51, and 1% for Europe's Brent crude, to below $59.

Options expiration can sometimes spark volatile trading, but that wasn't the case Friday as major averages showed tiny losses in late-afternoon trading.The Dow Jones industrial average and S&P 500 were mostly unchanged while the Nasdaq eased 0.1%. Volume was heavy early but trailed off. NYSE volume was tracking slightly higher than Thursday. Nasdaq volume fell a bit.In economic news, after three straight monthly declines, the University of Michigan said consumer sentiment rose in October to 92.1 from September's final reading of 87.2. The new reading was slightly better than expected.In the stock market today, fabless chip name Inphi (IPHI) extended gains after Thursday's breakout over a 27.21 entry. Shares rose another 3% after jumping nearly 8% Thursday.Inside the IBD 50 , NetEase (NTES) looked poised for its third-straight weekly price again. It's back above its 10-week moving average as it works on a cup-shaped base. Shares rose 5%.Cal-Maine Foods (CALM) rallied for the sixth straight session after giving up a 58.04 entry. It reclaimed the buy point Friday, rising nearly 5%.IBD 50 retailers Ulta Beauty (ULTA) and Foot Locker (FL) also outperformed, rising 3% and 2% respectively.In the railroad group, Kansas City Southern (KSU) got sidetracked. Shares slumped 10% on disappointing earnings.Follow Ken Shreve on Twitter: @IBD_KShreve and on Facebook.

Stocks rallied into the close after the Fed minutes indicated the central bank was concerned about global risks and inflation. The S&P 500 led with a 0.9% gain, the Dow Jones industrial average rose 0.8%, and the Nasdaq climbed 0.4%. Volume was lower across the board, according to preliminary data.Winners topped losers by a 3-1 margin on the NYSE and by a narrow 3-2 ratio on the Nasdaq, which was weighed down by software, biotech and Internet retailers.Railcar makers, energy and machinery-related stocks led the upside in the stock market today. Automakers underperformed again as Tesla Motors (TSLA) extended the current week's decline. Shares slid 2%, falling below the 200-day moving average in volume.Only four of the Dow's 30 components gave up ground. Apple (AAPL) was the biggest blue chip loser, slipping 1% as the iPhone maker continues to find resistance above the 110 level.Nike (NKE) ran up more than 2% to lead the Dow. Shares of the athletic shoe and apparel maker are extended 6% from a 117.82 buy point cleared Sept. 25 on a breakaway gap. Chevron (CVX) gained 2%, boosted by a 4% jump in crude oil prices.Among IBD 50 stocks, 32 advanced and 18 declined. Global Payments (GPN), surged 3% in fast trade, extending Wednesday's 11% gain on an earnings beat.Foot Locker (FL) was a big gainer too, jumping 3% in heavy volume. It's still below its 50-day line and a 75.05 buy point. Argus Research started coverage with a buy rating and an 88 price target.Follow Nancy Gondo on Twitter @IBD_NGondo.

The gain put it in the upper half of…
Stocks weakened going into the noon hour Wednesday as traders awaited the 2 p.m. ET release of minutes of the Federal Reserve's Sept 16-17 meeting.
It will be parsed for clues on when the Fed will begin raising interest rates.
The Nasdaq sagged 0.8%. The Dow inched up 0.1%, and the S&P 500 was down 0.1%.

EBay (EBAY) fell nearly 8% after ChannelAdvisor said clients selling on the online marketplace saw same-store sales rise 1.1% year-over-year in September, down from 3.4% in August and the slowest in 12 months.
Amazon (AMZN) saw same-store sales rise 19.2%, but that's down from 24.7% in August. Shares of Amazon fell 2%.

The Dow was held up by DuPont (DD), up 2%. The CEO announced her retirement earlier this week, fueling speculation of a company break-up. DuPont announced a strategic alliance with Caribou Biosciences.
Domino's Pizza (DPZ) fell flat, down 5% as it pierced its 200-day moving average. It reported EPS of 67 cents, well below estimates.
Among IBD 50 stocks, the top performer was Global Payments (GPN), up nearly 4% on top of Wednesday's 11% gain after reporting earnings that easily beat estimates.

Another IBD 50 name, Foot Locker (FL), rose more than 2%. Argus Research initiated coverage with a buy rating and an 88 price target. Tech stocks led a broad early rally Friday, as earnings surprises and foreign stimulus news buoyed global markets. The Nasdaq bolted ahead 2%. The S&P 500 climbed 1.1%. The Dow Jones industrial average lagged with a 0.8% gain.
Volume was mixed, rising 32% on the Nasdaq and dipping a fraction lower on the NYSE, in relation to trade at the same time Thursday.
While much of the week has been focused on company news and quarterly reports, the stock market today tapped into a wide range of influences.

The European Central Bank's news Thursday that it would consider additional stimulus measures in December launched a rally on global markets. China's central bank trimmed interest rates and announced a swathe of banking policy changes. U.S. markets received a psychological lift as both the Nasdaq and the S&P 500 punched decisively through resistance at their respective 200-day moving averages.

Another boost came from researcher Markit, whose preliminary manufacturing purchasing managers' index for October rose to 54, up from 53 in September and better than consensus views for a no-change reading.

Oil prices are worth watching, as West Texas Intermediate gave up early gains to trade 2% lower, below $45 a barrel, ahead of Baker-Hughes' weekly rig count report, due out at 1 p.m. ET. Oil is trading down more than 6% on the week, following a surprise surge in weekly inventories.
On top of all that, a raft of high-profile earnings wins sent some of the biggest tech names soaring in early trade.

Alphabet (GOOG) and Microsoft (MSFT) led the S&P 500 and the Nasdaq 100, up 11% and 10%, respectively after reporting third quarter surprises. The strong-volume gain lifted Alphabet nearly 6% past a 678.74 buy point in a 13-week cup base.
Amazon.com (AMZN) soared out of buying range, up 7% in heavy trade after reporting a surprise profit late Thursday.
Other notable gains included Ireland-based drugmaker Mallinckrodt (MNK), up 7%, and Verisign (VRSN) also leaping 7% to take a new high in strong trade after a strong Q3 report late Thursday.

Among leaders, more than 30% of the IBD 50 list stocks rose more than 1%. At the top of the list, Hawaiian Holdings (HA) surfed up 4% to snatch another new high in strong trade. The parent of Hawaiian Airlines has gained in 12 of the past 13 sessions and is extended after an early October breakout.
Noah Holdings (NOAH) gapped up to a 4% gain in heavy trade. The stock is trying to climb the right side of a deep consolidation.
At the bottom of the list, Foot Locker (FL) tumbled 6% in big trade, possibly stumbling in a sympathy moved linked to Skechers (SKX).
The session also provided some breathtaking losses.
Skechers dived 32% and Pandora (P) tanked 34% after broad earnings misses. Cabot Oil & Gas (COG) dropped 9%. VF Corp (VFC) tumbled 8%.

Stericycle (SRCL) folded 23% as Robert W. Baird downgraded the stock, to neutral from outperform, and lowered its price target to 130 from 145 after a weak Q3 report late Thursday. The drop sent the medical-waste-collection services provider below its 10-week line of support and deep below a 148.96 buy point.Tech stocks led a broad early rally Friday, as earnings surprises and foreign stimulus news buoyed global markets. At midweek, several recent New America stocks are in buy range and some are setting up bases.

Online food delivery startup GrubHub (GRUB), which is also an IBD Leaderboard stock, entered buy range from a 41.85 cup-with-handle buy point last week. It's up about 4% from that point through Wednesday's close, so it's still in buy range.
Foot Locker (FL), one of Nike 's (NKE) most important shoe retailers, has been setting up a base too.
IBD's The New America looks at fast-growing companies with sound technical stock performance indicators.
Watch this video for a quick analysis of GrubHub and Foot Locker charts, plus drug companies Mylan (MYL) and Lannett Co. (LCI).

Stocks ended with solid gains Friday after battling back from weakness spurred by a disappointing jobs report. The Nasdaq and the S&P 500 ended up 1.7% and 1.4%, respectively. Both were down 1.6% at Friday's low. The Dow Jones industrial average climbed 1.2%. According to preliminary data, volume ended higher across the board in the stock market today.Among leading stocks, Dave & Buster's Entertainment (PLAY) reversed higher to a 6% gain. The stock had already risen 3% Thursday, following the pricing of a share offering. Dave & Buster's was recently featured in Stock Spotlight.Verisk Analytics (VRSK) stretched its win streak to four straight sessions. It rebounded from a 2% loss and rose 2%. The stock nearly reached a 79.98 buy point in a flat base. Verisk, which provides data to insurance underwriters and banks, will be added to the S&P 500 after Wednesday's close.Tyler Technologies (TYL) added 2% for its second straight new high. It's now 15% past a 145.84 buy point from a flat base cleared Sept. 14. On Thursday, the company announced that it would buy privately held New World Systems for $670 million in cash and stock.Domino's Pizza (DPZ) climbed 0.5% after bucking morning weakness. It failed to retake its 200-day moving average. Domino's will report Q3 earnings Thursday. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters see the pizza chain's profit rising 17% to 74 cents a share..
Did consumers go in for basketball shoes, sneakers, sports gear and athletic apparel gear over the holidays?

Investors will find out when giant athletic footwear and apparel retail operator Foot Locker (FL) and sporting goods retailer Dick's Sporting Goods (DKS) report fourth-quarter financial results in coming days.
Foot Locker is rated highly by IBD and has logged at least double-digit profit growth in all but one of the past 16 quarters.

If analysts are on the money, Foot Locker is on track to keep up its streak when it reports fourth-quarter results before the stock market opens on Friday, March 6. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expect Foot Locker's fourth-quarter earnings to come in up 11% at 91 cents a share. While that would still be a healthy gain, it would be a slower pace than the 22% gain it saw in the third quarter.
They see sales rising 4.70% to $1.875 billion. That would be less of an increase than the 7% rise it saw in the third quarter.

If analysts are on target, Dick's will see fourth-quarter earnings rise 10% to $1.22 a share, when it reports results for the quarter before the stock market opens on Tuesday, March 3. That would be slightly faster than the 9% increase it saw in the prior quarter.
Dick's is expected to post an 8.8% rise in sales to $2.118 billion. That would be a quicker pace than the 2% increase it saw in the prior quarter.

Foot Locker is part of IBD's Retail/Apparel/Shoes/Accessories industry group, which also includes Ross Stores (ROST) and Lululemon Athletica (LULU) . Foot Locker has a 93 Composite Rating from IBD out of a possible 99, and is seen by analysts as one of the most important vendors of athletic shoes from Nike (NKE), which has a 90 Composite Rating.

Dick's is a part of IBD's Retail-Leisure Products industry group. The major indexes couldn't catch a break again Wednesday, although the market shaved its losses in the afternoon. The Nasdaq was staring at a 1.4% loss, sparked by a poor December U.S. retail sales report. But a rebound in the final two hours of the trading day cut that decline to 0.5%. Goldman Sachs downgraded the stock to sell from neutral and cut its price target to 47 from 55, saying margins reaped from basketball shoes — whose popularity has grown on recent offerings named after NBA stars…

Stocks seesawed to a lower finish on Veterans Day Wednesday. The Dow Jones industrial average, the Nasdaq and the S&P 500 all ended down 0.3%. According to preliminary data, volume was lower across the board in the stock market today.After the close, shares of Popeyes Louisiana Kitchen (PLKI) jumped more than 5% after the company posted Q3 results that beat views. The fried chicken chain reported earnings of 47 cents a share on sales of $61.1 million. Views were for 45 cents a share on revenue of $61.9 million. It also slightly raised its full-year profit outlook to a range of $1.86 to $1.91 a share, vs. views of $1.90.In the regular session, Horizon Pharma (HZNP) gapped down and plunged nearly 20% after pharmacy benefits manager Express Scripts (ESRX) filed a lawsuit against the company for $140 million over a contract dispute.AmTrust Financial Services (AFSI) gapped below its 50-day line and slumped 8% after pricing a secondary offering of 5 million shares. The insurance firm said that it would take in $315 million before expenses. Intraday, it fell more than 8% below a 69.84 buy point from a cup-with-handle base.Despite a rather lackluster session, TAL Education (XRS) rallied 3% and scored a new high in fast trade. It followed through Wednesday after clearing a 38.75 buy point from a late-stage cup-with-handle Tuesday. The company provides tutoring in China.Luxoft (LXFT) gapped up and jumped 7% after beating views and raising guidance. Late Tuesday, the company reported adjusted fiscal Q2 earnings of 84 cents a share, up 45% from a year earlier. Profit growth has now accelerated for two quarters. Sales rose 29% to $161.5 million. Luxoft lifted its full-year profit outlook by a nickel to $2.60 a share. The stock is now extended 9% past a 68.95 buy point from a flat base.Weekly jobless claims will be out Thursday morning. A host of central bank officials will be speaking throughout the day, including Fed Chairwoman Janet Yellen, St. Louis Fed chief James Bullard and Richmond Fed President Jeffrey Lacker.Advance Auto Parts (AAP) and Cisco Systems (CSCO) are a couple of notable companies reporting earnings Thursday.Follow Vincent Mao on Twitter @IBD_VMao.

November and December combined shopping-center sales rose 3.6% vs. a year earlier to $487.1 billion, marking the best performance for a holiday season since 2011, the ICSC…

Stocks finished lower but well off the lows of the day Wednesday as BlackBerry abruptly zoomed 30% on a Reuters report that it had been approached by Samsung regarding a possible takeover.BlackBerry's (BBRY) stock caught fire near 3:30 p.m. ET. The report said Samsung was prepared to pay as much as $7.5 billion for access to patents, quoting a person familiar with the talks and documentshttp://finance.yahoo.com/news/exclusive-samsung-makes-takeover-approach-205037341.html. The onetime pioneer in smartphones has seen its revenue and earnings decline in recent years.The Nasdaq fell 0.5%, the S&P 500 dropped 0.6% and the Dow Jones industrial average lost 1.1%. Volume rose on the NYSE and fell on the Nasdaq compared with Tuesday's action, according to preliminary figures.Electric carmaker Tesla (TSLA) plunged on CEO Elon Musk's late-Tuesday comment at the Detroit Auto Show that Q4 sales in China were unexpectedly weak.Tesla gapped down and closed at its lowest level since May 2014 in heavy volume. It was down nearly 6% in the stock market today.Among IBD 50 stocks, 15 were higher and 35 were lower. The best performer was volatile teen retailer Five Below (FIVE), up more than 4% after a three-day sell-off. The worst performer was Foot Locker (FL), down nearly 4% on a downgrade to sell from neutral by Goldman Sachs.A combination of a slowing global growth forecast by the World Bank, weaker-than-expected retail sales and poor earnings from JPMorgan Chase (JPM) combined to get the market off to a weak start in the morning. JPMorgan was the worst performer in the Dow, down nearly 4%. Walmart (WMT) fell more than 3%.

Retail and construction stocks got a lift Wednesday after a better-than-expected gain in private payrolls suggested the economy remains in good shape. Private employers added 241,000 jobs in December, according to payroll processor ADP. That beat forecasts for an increase of 235,000 jobs. The buoyant job figures suggested the world's biggest economy remains on track despite slowdowns in Europe, China…
Finish Line (FINL) shares plunged Friday after it reported a surprise third-quarter loss.
The athletic shoe retailer swung to a loss of 2 cents per share from a 6-cent-per-share profit in the year-ago quarter. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters were expecting a 1-cent-per-share profit.
Sales climbed 8.6% to $395.8 million, beating views for $390.95 million. Comparable store sales rose 4.5%
"Third-quarter comparable sales rebounded from second-quarter trends, however merchandise margin pressure kept us from achieving our profitability plan," CEO Glenn Lyon said in the earnings release.
Shares sank 21% on the stock market today, diving far below both its 50-day and 200-day moving averages. The stock is at its lowest level since September 2013.
Rival Foot Locker (FL) tumbled 8%, also cutting through its 50-day line.

Finish Line sees flat fiscal 2015 EPS vs. a 2014 EPS of $1.67. Analysts are expecting $1.79. The company lowered its same-store sales projection to a low- to mid-single digit increase vs. an earlier outlook for same-store sales to be up mid-single digits.

Athletic shoes and apparel sales have been strong during the holiday season. Athletic footwear sales were up 11% to $977.3 million during the five weeks ended Dec. 6, according to a report Thursday from the NPD Group.

Late Thursday, Nike (NKE) reported Q2 results that topped expectations on sales gains in the North American and European markets. But global futures orders rose at the slowest rate in four quarters and missed expectations.
Shares were down 3% Friday.

Basketball shoes scored the highest gains in athletic footwear sales in the five weeks ending Dec. 6, according to the NPD Group in a report released Thursday.
Athletic footwear sales overall did well, with sales up 11% — or $93 million — from a year earlier to $977.3 million.
But basketball footwear grew much faster, at 24%, accounting for $50 million of the $93 million increase, researcher NPD Group said.
While basketball footwear "continues to gain momentum," consumers are also paying up for it, NPD noted. Some 50% of all basketball shoes sold were at price points over $100, compared to 35% in 2012.

Nike's (NKE) Brand Jordan took the lead over Thanksgiving week, nabbing $28 million out of the $37.3 million total in basketball footwear sales between Nov. 23-29. Nearly all of Brand Jordan's sales then came from one shoe: the Jordan IV Retro Mid.

"Basketball footwear is on fire, and it's the premium price points that continue to drive the market," noted Matt Powell, vice president of industry analysis at the NPD Group. He said sales of basketball shoes over $100 accounted for nearly all of the growth.
He expects basketball footwear sales momentum to continue into 2015 as the largest brands remain focused on controlling inventory, helping to keep interest and demand high.
Other basketball footwear brands include Germany's Adidas and Baltimore-based Under Armour (UA).

While it runs retail stores, mostly outlets, Under Armour is largely a wholesaler. Like retailer/wholesaler Nike, Under Armour shoes are sold in footwear chains such as Foot Locker (FL) and Finish Line (FINL).

Frank Woolworth changed the retail landscape of America by keeping things simple and staying true to his beliefs.He founded F.W. Woolworth & Co. in 1879. The five-and-dime store chain, with its distinctive gold lettering and red awnings, made him one of the richest men in America."For more than a century, Americans shopped at Woolworth's five-and-tens," wrote Jean Maddern Pitrone in "F.W. Woolworth and the American Five and Dime." "These stores were as American as apple pie, baseball and Norman Rockwell paintings."It was all a labor of love, as Woolworth was quoted as saying in "Five And Ten: The Fabulous Life of F.W. Woolworth" by John Winkler: "No man can make a success of a business which he does not like."Hard work was another Woolworth staple. "There are plenty of opportunities today," he said. "Many young men fail because they are not willing to sacrifice."Come On InWoolworth made sure to provide customers an enjoyable shopping experience at his five-and-dime stores. "Make it a rule not to bore or annoy customers," he wrote to his store managers. "Let them look around to their heart's content. Don't try and press goods on them. ... Make your customers feel at home. ... Encourage people to meet their friends in your store. Give them something free."His strategy led to riches. The estate of Woolworth (1852-1919), according to the Watertown, N.Y., city website, was estimated at $27 million when he died — $364 million in today 's money.Also by 1919, F.W. Woolworth & Co. operated some 1,100 U.S. stores and 90 in Britain and Ireland, with annual sales of over $100 million, or $1.4 billion today.A bronze bust of Woolworth, along with seven other industry giants, stands near the Merchandise Mart in Chicago.Paul Seaton, author of "A Sixpenny Romance: Celebrating a Century of Value at Woolworths," wrote of the founder's "dogged determination, refusing to take no for an answer."Seaton told IBD: "To achieve his goal of a successful chain of fixed-price stores, Frank didn't just buy from wholesalers and traveling salesmen. Line by line, he traced his products back to their sources, all over the world, and persuaded the manufacturers to deal direct."Winkler concluded that all great ideas are traceable to a "tenacious, believing individual. So it was in this case. Frank Woolworth clung to his belief in the future of the five-and-ten" — a term that came from his selling nothing for over 10 cents, a practice that lasted until the 1930s.In lower Manhattan, he built the Woolworth Building, which towered nearly 800 feet high and for a time was the tallest skyscraper in the world.Woolworth's personal stature was so high, President Wilson drew him to his World War I Cabinet and tasked him with the responsibility of fundraising.By 1954, the number of Woolworth stores worldwide had grown to 2,800.But in 1997, Woolworth's went out of business and was absorbed into what is now Foot Locker (FL).Woolworth was born in Rodman, N.Y. His father was a farmer who went off to fight for the Union in the Civil War, reaching the rank of captain. Frank grew up working on the farm, much to his disdain."My youth," he said in 1911, "was the worst time of my life."Farming taught him what he didn't want to do in life. "He hated the blisters and calluses on his hands," Pitrone wrote. The boy also couldn't stand working the farm implements in the cold.Frank's teachers considered him a bit of a dreamer, Seaton wrote on WoolworthsMuseum.co.uk.Woolworth would reflect years later that "dreaming never hurt anybody if he keeps working right behind the dream."The future five-and-dime giant might have dreamt of such an outlet after he and his younger brother Charles were laughed at in a nearby Watertown department store while pondering a birthday present for their mom. Their crime? Wanting to pay with loose change."Frank walked out and bought a similar item in another shop where the staff were more polite," Seaton wrote. "In later life, he recalled the event and how he had told to his brother that one day people would be able to buy five or even 10 items for 50 cents, and shops would give helpful and friendly service to everyone, both rich and poor."Farm, School, BusinessAfter leaving school at age 16 to work full time on the family farm, Woolworth figured a way out. He asked his mother to send him to night school to learn book keeping.She did. With her backing, the boy escaped the farm for life in business. By age 21, he had a sales position with a dry-goods store."In his first job fresh off the farm at a retail store, he was humble and willing to do what was necessary with effort and dedication to prove his point," John Compton, who worked 43 years at Woolworth's, told IBD.In 1876, Woolworth married Jennie Creighton, whom his parents had hired as his nurse when he fell ill due to exhaustion and stress. Frank and Jennie would have three daughters.He excelled especially at merchandising. The next year, the dry-goods store wound up with a pile of unsold inventory. Woolworth was tabbed to create a table display where everything was on sale for 5 cents.He did so expertly, and the merchandise sold out.Finding his calling, Woolworth decided to open a five-and-dime store and approached his family for financial backing.The answer was no. Refusing to fold, he appealed to one of his employers, William Moore, who offered him some merchandise on credit. Woolworth was in business.Down, Not OutAfter first opening a store in Utica, N.Y., that failed, he opened one in Lancaster, Pa., in June 1879."He became convinced that his failure in Utica was ... mainly due to the poor location of his store and Utica itself," Winkler wrote.In Utica, he'd sold merchandise at only one price: five cents.In Lancaster, he sparked what Winkler calls the first successful five-and-dime chain in the world.Woolworth was alerted to Lancaster by a friend who gave him a glowing account of the city and reason to believe that the thrifty Dutch population would welcome his store, Winkler wrote. Two years later came a second one in Harrisburg, managed by Charles.Woolworth believed in the power of merchandising."You don't have to bark for customers," he wrote a store manager in the 1890s. "That method is too ancient for us. But you can pull customers into your stores, and they won't know it. Draw them in with attractive window displays, and when you get them in, have a plentiful showing of the window goods on the counters."By then, Woolworth had shifted into high gear, targeting cities east of the Rockies for 10 store openings a year. A few years later, he wrote, "I have been looking over a census of the United States, and I am convinced that there are 100 cities and towns where we can locate (five-and-dime) cent stores."He learned early from mistakes. "Some of my first stores failed because I placed them in the wrong part of town," he said. "There's always a right location. Find it."Said Compton: "Woolworth never gave up. In his failures, he would regroup and try again but making sure he did not repeat the causes of his earlier failures."Woolworth made store openings gala events. Saturday starts were preceded by Friday-afternoon receptions of prominent people from each neighborhood. Orchestras enlivened the parties.Over a quarter-century beginning in 1879, Woolworth and Charles enticed family and former co-workers to open five-and-dime stores across North America.Woolworth created a buying consortium known as the Friendly Rival Syndicate. Five independent chains pooled ideas and shared common merchandise. In November 1909, the first British Woolworth's opened in Liverpool.By then, F.W. Woolworth & Co. shares were sold to store managers, family members and suppliers."He showed extreme loyalty to the people he trusted, helping them through difficult times and rewarding their loyalty," Seaton said. "All of his first managers became directors and VPs, and became immensely rich. Staff across the organization knew him as a kindly, hard-working man who paid everyone a Christmas bonus and gave paid holidays long before this was the norm, but also a man who should not be crossed and expected discretion, hard work and loyalty ... or else!"On Top Of ItWinkler recounted how Woolworth often traveled his store circuit, dropping in unannounced — and pity "the manager whose counters, shelves or windows were slovenly. To him, the boss seemed ubiquitous. He particularly abhorred cheap and hasty window displays, and would often jump in himself and decorate."Seaton said: "Frank embodied the adage 'retail is detail.'"Woolworth had a single-minded focus in putting his stores on top and didn't let setbacks stop him."Of course you will be discouraged," he said of the ups and downs in business. "But keep on."

Despite weak golf and hunting equipment sales, Dick's Sporting Goods (DKS) edged past analysts' earnings and sales forecasts, sending shares up Tuesday. The sporting-goods retailer earned 67 cents a share excluding a $20.4 million pretax golf restructuring charge, a 5.6% fall from the same quarter last year. Analysts had expected 65 cents a share. Revenue rose 10.3% to $1.69 billion…

The IBD 50 finds itself with few signs of distress, and a fair share of success stories even as the market's uptrend moderates. It's been a month since the market started climbing from its August lows, and the main indexes have slowed their ascent. Despite that, there's little to complain about in the IBD 50. Nearly half of the 50…
Retailers likely saw sales heat up in August as back-to-school shopping kicked into high gear with consumers spending more freely on electronics, classroom supplies and clothing.

IBD Leaderboard stock Under Armour (UA) is among the activewear and sporting goods companies expected to fare well in back-to-school shopping, given the trends. Highly rated Foot Locker (FL) and Finish Line (FINL) could also benefit.
As of Wednesday, analysts were expecting August retail industry sales at stores open at least a year to rise 4.2% vs. a year earlier, according to Ken Perkins, president of Retail Metrics.
The final tally for August, the key back-to-school selling month, will be released Thursday.
All retailers reporting same-store sales are expected to show positive same-store sales growth, Perkins says.

"The estimates reflect a moderately decent back-to-school shopping period," Perkins told IBD. "Traffic picked as the month progressed. Retailers were very promotional making it worthwhile for people to get out and shop. It should turn out to be an OK back-to-school shopping season, unlike last year, which was very difficult. That doesn't mean that all retailers fared well, because it's very competitive and cutthroat out there.
Retailers, he adds, need to have the "right product mix as well as the right price points" to have a good back-to-school season.

Among the 11 retailers that report monthly same-store sales Perkins cites action-sports retailer Zumiez (ZUMZ) as one that's positioned to fare well for back-to-school. It gets a Composite Rating of 89 from IBD, out of a possible 99.
Perkins says Zumiez is "best placed" among the publicly traded teen-apparel retailers to perform the best for back to school, citing the fact that it operates in a niche area as a positive.
That sports-related niche is likely helping Zumiez ride the crest of the athleticwear wave that's sweeping the apparel industry and likely to be the big winner for back-to-school.
Investors will learn more about how Zumiez is faring when it reports second-quarter results on Thursday after the closing bell.

Separately, power brands such as Nike (NKE) and Under Armour (which has an IBD Composite Rating of 98) are seen cashing in on the back-to-school buying spree in athletic attire as are athletic footwear retailers Foot Locker and Finish Line, which hold a 98 and 94 IBD Composite Rating, respectively.
Gap's Old Navy brand is seen having a good August, says Perkins. As of Wednesday, Old Navy was expected to show a 3.6% rise in August same-store sales vs. a year earlier.
But overall, Gap (GPS) is seen posting August same-store sales up 1.7% vs. a year earlier. Gap gets an IBD Composite Rating of 89.
"Things are tough at the company's namesake brand," Perkins said.

Warehouse club powerhouse and typical top retail performer Costco Wholesale (COST) is expected to generate the strongest August same-store sales gain at 4.9%. Core Costco U.S. same-store sales that exclude gas and foreign currency are projected to rise a slightly greater 5.2%.
Giant drugstore operator Walgreen (WAG) is expected to post a solid 4.4% rise in same-store sales for August. Rival Rite Aid (RAD) is estimated to post a 3.3% gain.
Victoria's Secret parent L Brands (LB) is forecast to show a 2.8% same-store sales gain for August.
Regional discount chain Stein Mart (SMRT) is projected to report a 3% rise.
PriceSmart (PSMT), which owns and operates U.S.-style membership shopping warehouses in Latin America and the Caribbean, is expected to see a 1.1% increase for the month.
Teen-apparel retailer Buckle (BKE) is seen showing a 1.1% rise.

Stocks ended mixed in slow trade Friday as the market greeted Federal Reserve chief Janet Yellen's speech with a yawn. The Nasdaq tacked on 0.1%, while the S&P 500 retreated 0.2%. The IBD 50 strode 0.5% higher. Volume fell across the board. Yellen's speech at the annual conference in Jackson Hole, Wyo., repeated themes that she had emphasized before. She…
Stocks pulsed higher at the start of trade Friday, with company news squarely in the spotlight.
The Dow Jones industrial average and the S&P 500 climbed 0.2% apiece. The Nasdaq stuck to a 0.1% gain.
Volume was sharply mixed, up 11% on the NYSE and 25% lower on the Nasdaq, compared with trade at the same time Thursday.
The stock market today opened to some notable events.

Apple (AAPL) eased a bit less than 1% as Apple stores worldwide began taking orders for the new Apple Watch. All devices in the U.S. had "almost entirely sold out" in less than six hours, according to the Apple intelligence site 9TO5Mac. Minimum order times were four to six weeks, the site reported. Apple shares are sitting on their 10-week moving average within a seven-week flat base.

General Electric (GE) surged 9%, hauling the Dow higher. The diversified heavyweight announced a restructuring program that includes plans to divest most of its GE Capital service operations over the next two years. The company said it had lined up buyers, led by Blackstone Group (BX) and Wells Fargo (WFC), for most of its commercial real estate portfolio. It announced a $50 billion share buyback initiative. GE leapt past highs from February and November, sending shares to their highest mark since June.

Netflix (NFLX) climbed 2% after Citigroup upgraded shares to buy from neutral and raised its price target to 525 from 409. The gain boosted shares back above their 10-week moving average and put the stock up 8% for the week.

Citrix Systems (CTXS) dropped more than 4% after management trimmed the software developer's Q1 earnings and revenue guidance after Thursday's close. The company cited an unexpected impact from its restructuring. William Blair downgraded the stock to market perform from outperform. Shares have been consolidating since September.

Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) jumped 4% in heavy trade, retaking its converged 10- and 40-week moving averages. Stocks made gains for the third straight day Friday, but they lacked the power of Wednesday's and Thursday's advances, even though volume was higher because of quadruple witching.
The Nasdaq rose 0.4%, the S&P 500 gained 0.5% and the Dow Jones industrial average was ahead 0.2%.
A few earnings reports and a new issue dominated the session.

CarMax (KMX) gapped up and closed more than 10% higher in the stock market today after reporting a 28% increase in earnings from a year ago. It was the same with work uniform provider Cintas (CTAS), which gapped up and closed nearly 5% higher after reporting a 26% earnings gain.

Among IBD 50 stocks, 30 were higher and 20 were lower. The worst performer was Foot Locker (FL), down 7% in sympathy with Finish Line (FINL), which reported an earnings decline and lowered guidance, citing a weak retail environment.
Fellow sneaker maker Nike (NKE) also fell nearly 2%, but finished the day in the upper half of its daily range.
Biotech company Juno Therapeutics (JUNO) came public with fireworks, closing up 46% from a 24 offering price.

Depressed oil and gas industry groups were the day's best performers as the price of oil rose nearly 7%. CarMax (KMX) gapped up and closed more than 10% higher in the stock market today after reporting a 28% increase in earnings from a year ago. It was the same with work uniform provider Cintas (CTAS), which gapped up and closed nearly 5% higher after reporting a 26% earnings gain.Among IBD 50 stocks, 30 were higher and 20 were lower. The worst performer was Foot Locker (FL), down 7% in sympathy with Finish Line (FINL), which reported an earnings decline and lowered guidance, citing a weak retail environment.Fellow sneaker maker Nike (NKE) also fell nearly 2%, but finished the day in the upper half of its daily range.Biotech company Juno Therapeutics (JUNO) came public with fireworks, closing up 46% from a 24 offering price.Depressed oil and gas industry groups were the day's best performers as the price of oil rose nearly 7%. Retail stocks were among the worst performers.
Foot Locker stepped past third-quarter earnings and sales estimates Friday as the sports retailer continued to cash in on the basketball shoe buying craze.
But after rallying early to a record 59.19, the IBD 50 stock reversed to end down 4% to 54.58 amid ongoing apparel woes.

"It may be the belief that the company is executing at such a high level that it may be difficult to surpass ... which we disagree with," said Canaccord Genuity analyst Camilo Lyon. "They're executing very well. (But) I think there's still room for further improvement, mainly in apparel."
Foot Locker earnings rose 22% to 83 cents a share. Analysts saw 79 cents.
Sales grew 6.7% to $1.731 billion, topping estimates for $1.720 billion. Same-store sales rose a healthy 6.9%, with footwear up low-double-digits.
Lyon says basketball shoes continue to be the strongest performing part of the sector.
Foot Locker (FL) has always been the "go-to" place for basketball, noted John Horan, publisher of weekly newsletter Sporting Goods Intelligence.

"The quarter was a lot better than the stock market is giving Foot Locker credit for," said Brian Sozzi, CEO of Belus Capital Advisors. "You're seeing very strong sales in the Nike (NKE) Jordan, Kobe and LeBron (shoe) lines. All those marquee names from Nike are winning big. Foot Locker hit on all the right buttons for me."
Lyon called Q3 "solid."

"I was impressed by its ability to comp significantly above its peer group despite the challenges of having two major (Nike basketball shoe) launches — the LeBron 12 and the Jordan Retro — shifted to the fourth quarter."
Foot Locker said November comps growth so far is in the low-double digits. The Jordan Retro launched on Nov. 15.

Added Sozzi: "What other specialty retailer in the mall has been putting up those types of numbers thus far in November? There's no reason to believe that Foot Locker will not have a strong holiday season."
Sozzi did note that apparel remains an "ongoing struggle" for Foot Locker, with Q3 comps down in the mid-single digits.
Meanwhile, CEO Ken Hicks said he will retire Dec. 1. He will be succeeded by Chief Operating Officer Dick Johnson.
Separately, sporting goods retailer Hibbett Sports (HIBB) reported Q3 EPS of 67 cents, 1 cent more than a year earlier and ahead of forecasts for 62 cents.
Sales rose 5% to $218.3 million, shy of views for $221.13 million.

Hibbett stock rose 4% to 47.75. It's still down 29% in 2014.Foot Locker stepped past third-quarter earnings and sales estimates Friday as the sports retailer continued to cash in on the basketball shoe buying craze.But after rallying early to a record 59.19, the IBD 50 stock reversed to end down 4% to 54.58 amid ongoing apparel woes."It may be the belief that the company is executing at such a high level that it may be difficult to surpass ... which we disagree with," said Canaccord Genuity analyst Camilo Lyon. Stock snapped lower in quiet trade at Wednesday's open.
The Dow Jones industrial average and the S&P 500 shed 1.1% apiece. The Nasdaq slipped 1.3%.
Volume was soft in the stock market today, down 13% on the Nasdaq and 27% lower on the NYSE, compared with action at the same time Tuesday.
Investors are looking toward this afternoon's release of minutes from the Federal Open Market Committee's June 17 meeting, set for 2 p.m. ET.

The word out of the eurozone sounded generally positive, as news reports said Greece formally requested a three-year bailout and offered to implement tax and pension-related changes by as soon as next week. Eurozone leaders gave Greece an end-of-this-week deadline to come up with a workable agreement in order to secure bailout funding to prop up the country's economy and banking system. Greek banks and its stock market remain closed, with only limited withdrawals permitted from ATMs.
The recent sell-off in China's stock markets rippled more broadly into world markets Wednesday. Both the Shanghai Composite and the Hang Seng index in Hong Kong fell nearly 6% overnight.
There was plenty of other news.
Microsoft (MSFT) eased a fraction after announcing it would lay off 7,800 workers and take a $7.6 billion writedown related to problems with its Nokia phone business.
Barclays (BCS) dropped 1%. The bank's board fired CEO Antony Jenkins and expanded the role of chairman John McFarlane to cover the position until a new CEO is found.

United Airlines (UAL) dipped 2% after temporarily halting a large number of its flights Wednesday morning due to "network connectivity issues." The Federal Aviation Administration reported the airline had lifted the shutdown by midmorning.
Chipmakers were under heavy selling pressure in early trade.
NXP Semiconductors (NXPI) shed 4%, deepening its correction and putting it 19% below an early June high.
Singapore-based Avago Technologies (AVGO) fell almost 4%. The stock is now 15% below an early June high and below its 10-week moving average.

Leaders took their licks along with the rest of the market. On the IBD 50 list, Skyworks Solutions (SWKS) and Epam Systems (EPAM) dropped 4% each. At the same time, Horizon Pharma (HZNP) and Criteo (CRTO) both posted 2% gains.Stock snapped lower in quiet trade at Wednesday's open.The Dow Jones industrial average and the S&P 500 shed 1.1% apiece.
